ⲉⲧⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲉⲛⲙⲟⲟϣⲉ ⲁⲛⲉⲓ ⲉⲡⲧⲟⲟⲩ ⲛⲧⲉⲧⲕⲟⲟϩ , ⲡⲉⲓⲧⲟⲟⲩ ⲛⲧⲁⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ϩⲱⲛ ⲙⲡϥⲥⲙⲟⲩ ⲉⲩⲱⲛϩ ϣⲁⲉⲛⲉϩ ·
ⲁⲛϭⲟⲓⲗⲉ ⲉϩⲉⲛⲥⲛⲏⲩ ⲙⲙⲁⲓⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲉⲩϩⲙⲡⲧⲟⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲁⲩⲉⲓⲣⲉ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲛⲟϭ ⲙⲡⲉⲧⲛⲁⲛⲟⲩϥ ⲛⲙⲙⲁⲛ ·
ⲡⲉⲛⲙⲁⲕⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲥⲟⲛ ⲁⲡⲁ ⲫⲓϥ ⲁϥⲙⲧⲟⲛ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ϩⲛⲥⲟⲩϫⲟⲩⲧⲏ ⲙⲡⲁⲟⲡⲉ ⲙⲡⲛⲁⲩ ⲛϫⲡϣⲟⲙⲧⲉ ⲙⲡⲉϩⲟⲟⲩ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁⲛⲙⲕⲁϩ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ⲉⲁⲛⲟⲩⲱⲗⲥ ⲛϩⲏⲧ ⲛⲥⲱϥ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲗⲩⲡⲏ ·
ⲁⲛ ⲧⲱⲙⲥ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ·

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ▢ ⲡⲁⲓ ⲡⲉ ⲡⲃⲓⲟⲥ ⲙⲡⲙⲁⲕⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲡⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲛⲧⲉⲗⲓⲟⲛ ⲡⲁⲓ ⲛⲧⲁⲛⲉϥⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ ⲥⲙⲓⲛⲉ ⲛⲁϥ ⲙⲡⲉⲩⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲓⲟⲛ ⲛⲛⲟⲩⲃ ·
Translation: HERE BEGINNETH THE LIFE OF THE BLESSED JOHN, THE PERFECT MONK, WHOSE PARENTS MADE FOR HIM A GOSPEL OF GOLD

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲉⲁϥϫⲱⲕ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲙⲡⲉϥⲃⲓⲟⲥ ⲉⲧⲛⲁⲛⲟⲩϥ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲙⲛⲧⲧⲉⲗⲓⲟⲥ ⲙⲛⲟⲩϩⲩⲡⲟⲙⲟⲛⲏ ⲉⲛⲁⲛⲟⲩⲥ · ⲛⲥⲟⲩϥⲧⲟⲟⲩ ⲙⲡⲉⲃⲟⲧ · ⲙϣⲓⲣ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲉⲓⲣⲏⲛⲏ ⲛⲧⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲥⲙⲟⲩ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ⲧⲏⲣⲛ ϩⲁⲙⲏⲛ ⁛—
Translation: AND WHO ENDED HIS LIFE, WITH THE MOST EXCELLENT PATIENT ENDURANCE, ON THE FOURTH DAY OF THE MONTH MEKHIR, IN THE PEACE OF GOD. PRAY FOR US ALL! AMEN.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: —ⲡⲉⲓⲃⲓⲟⲥ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲧⲉⲛⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲓⲛⲁϣⲁϫⲉ ⲛⲙⲙⲏⲧⲛ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧϥ · ⲡⲁⲣⲁⲟⲩⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲡⲉ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛϣⲟⲩⲣϣⲡⲏⲣⲉ
Translation: This life which I will now describe unto you is that of a man of God, who lived in our time, and it must be regarded with wonder.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲁⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲉⲣⲉϣⲟⲙⲛⲧ ⲛϣⲏⲣⲉ ϣⲟⲟⲡ ⲛⲁⲩ ·
Translation: And they had three children.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉⲥⲛⲁⲩ
Translation: Now two of these had been appointed to high positions in the Palace of the Emperors,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲕⲟⲩⲓ ϩⲱⲱϥ ⲁⲩⲧⲁⲁϥ ⲉⲧⲣⲉϥϫⲓⲥⲃⲱ ⲉⲛⲉϩⲃⲏⲩⲉ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: and the youngest had been sent to receive instruction in the works of God.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲁⲛⲁⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥⲉⲓⲙⲉ ⲉⲛⲱϣ ⲛⲛⲉⲥⲭⲟⲗⲁⲥⲧⲓⲕⲟⲥ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛⲉϥϩⲛⲧⲉⲩⲙⲏⲏⲧⲉ ⲡⲉ ·
Translation: And after these things he learned the teachings of the wise men, and associated with them.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲁⲗⲓⲛ ⲟⲛ · ⲁϥⲧⲥⲁⲃⲟ ⲛⲛⲉϩⲃⲏⲩⲉ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛϥⲙⲏⲣ ⲉⲧⲉⲕⲕⲗⲏⲥⲓⲁ ⲉϥϣⲓⲛⲉ ⲛⲥⲁⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ · ⲙⲡⲉϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲙⲛⲧⲉⲩϣⲏ ·
Translation: Moreover he learned the works of God, and attached himself to the church, making enquiries concerning God by day and by night.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲁⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥϣⲁϫⲉ ⲙⲛⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ϩⲁϩⲧⲛⲡⲉϥⲏⲓ · ϩⲙⲡϣⲁϫⲉ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And this monk spake unto John inside his house with the words of God,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲣϣⲡⲏⲣⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲉⲡⲉϩⲟⲩⲟ · ⲉϥⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲡⲥⲟⲛ ⲙⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲙⲛⲡⲉϥⲥⲭⲏⲙⲁ · ⲙⲛⲧⲉϥϭⲓⲛϣⲁϫⲉ ⲉⲧϩⲟⲗϭ ⲙⲛⲛⲉϥⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ · ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲟⲩⲕⲱϩⲧ ⁛
Translation: and John marvelled exceedingly when he saw the monkish brother, and his garb, and perceived his pleasant manner of speech, and his internal thought about God, which was like fire.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲡⲥⲟⲛ ⲙⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲉⲓϣⲟⲟⲡ ϩⲛⲧⲙⲟⲛⲏ ⲛⲛⲉⲧⲉⲙⲉⲩⲛⲕⲟⲧⲕ ·
Translation: The monkish brother said unto him, 'I live in the Monastery of the Sleepless Ones.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲉⲣϣⲁⲛⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲣϩⲛⲁϥ ⲉⲓⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲉⲃⲱⲕ ⲉⲧϩⲓⲉⲣⲟⲩⲥⲁⲗⲏⲙ ⲛⲧⲁϣⲗⲏⲗ ⲙⲙⲁⲩ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲟⲩⲁⲁⲃ · ⲁⲩⲱ ϩⲙⲡⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ · ϯⲛⲁⲕⲧⲟⲓ ⲉⲡⲁⲙⲁ ⲛⲕⲉⲥⲟⲡ ·
Translation: And if God pleaseth I wish to go to Jerusalem so that I may pray there in the Holy Place, and, by the will of God, I will return again to my place.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁⲡⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲧⲁⲙⲟϥ ⲉⲧⲃⲉϩⲱⲃ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲛⲧⲁⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲧⲁⲙⲟϥ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧϥ ·
Translation: And the monk informed him concerning everything about which John enquired of him.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲉϥⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲇⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲉⲛⲉⲓϣⲁϫⲉ ⲁϥⲁⲙⲁϩⲧⲉ ⲛⲧϭⲓϫ ⲙⲡⲥⲟⲛ ⲙⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲁϥϫⲓⲧϥ ⲉⲩⲙⲁ ⲉϥⲉⲥⲩⲭⲁⲍⲉ
Translation: And when John had heard these words he laid hold upon the hand of the monkish brother, and took him to a place which was quiet and secret,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁϥⲧⲁⲣⲕⲟϥ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲁⲛⲁϣ ⲉϥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉⲉⲕϣⲁⲛⲃⲱⲕ ⲡⲁⲙⲉⲣⲓⲧ ⲛⲥⲟⲛ ⲉⲧϩⲓⲉⲣⲟⲩⲥⲁⲗⲏⲙ ⲛⲅⲕⲟⲧⲕ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲉⲓⲣⲏⲛⲏ ⲙⲡⲣϩⲟⲡⲕ ⲉⲣⲟⲓ ·
Translation: and he made him to swear great oaths, saying unto him, 'My beloved brother, when thou hast gone to Jerusalem, and hast returned in peace, thou shalt not hide thyself from me,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩⲇⲉ ⲙⲡⲣⲃⲱⲕ ⲉⲧⲉⲕⲙⲟⲛⲏ ⲛⲅⲕⲁⲁⲧ ⲛⲥⲱⲕ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϫⲉⲛϯϩⲡⲗⲁⲁⲩ ⲁⲛ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ϩⲙⲡⲁⲃⲓⲟⲥ ⲧⲏⲣϥ · ⲉⲡⲉⲓⲇⲏ ⲛⲁⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ ⲙⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲓ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ⲡⲁⲣⲁⲛⲁⲥⲛⲏⲩ ·
Translation: neither shalt thou depart to thy monastery and forsake me, and I will not hide anything from thee during the whole course of my life. My parents, however, love me very much more than they love my brethren,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲁⲩⲧⲁⲁⲧ ⲉⲧⲟⲟⲧⲟⲩ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲥⲭⲟⲗⲁⲥⲧⲓⲕⲟⲥ ·
Translation: for they have placed me in the hands of instructors,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲉⲣⲉⲡⲁⲉⲓⲱⲧ ϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉϯⲛⲁϯ ⲛⲁⲕ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲧⲁⲝⲓⲥ ·
Translation: and my father saith, 'I will give thee high offices.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲗⲟⲓⲡⲟⲛ ⲕⲁⲧⲁⲛⲉⲧϩⲙⲡⲉϥϩⲏⲧ ⲉϥⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲉϯ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲛⲕⲉⲥⲁϣϥ ⲛⲧⲁⲝⲓⲥ ⲉⲩϫⲟⲥⲉ ⲡⲁⲣⲁⲧⲱϥ ·
Translation: Moreover, according to what is in his heart, he wisheth to give me seven offices, each of which is more exalted than his own.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲁⲛⲁⲓ ⲉϥⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲉⲛⲣϣⲉⲗⲉⲉⲧ ⲉⲣⲟⲓ ·
Translation: After these things he wisheth to make me a bridegroom.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ
Translation: And, moreover, when I go into the church I hear them proclaiming and saying, 'Everything in this world is contemptible,' and 'Let him that despiseth this world follow the Christ with a right heart,' and even so he shall hardly be saved.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲁⲛⲁⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥϫⲓϣⲟϫⲛⲉ ϩⲙⲡⲉϥϩⲏⲧ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲙⲁⲕⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲉϥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲡⲣⲱⲧⲱⲛ ⲙⲉⲛ ⲕⲁⲁⲧ ⲛⲧⲁⲃⲱⲕ ϣⲁⲛⲁⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲧⲣⲉⲩⲥⲙⲓⲛⲉ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲛⲟⲩⲉⲩⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲓⲟⲛ ⲛⲧⲁⲱϣ ϩⲓⲱⲱϥ · ϫⲉⲛϯⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ ⲁⲛ ⲛⲛⲉⲛⲧⲟⲗⲏ ⲙⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ·
Translation: And after these things the blessed John took counsel with himself, saying, 'First of all let me go to my parents, so that i may make them prepare for me a Gospel wherein I may read, for I do not know the commandments of Christ,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲟⲛ ϯⲛⲁϭⲛⲧϥ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ ⲉⲧϯⲛⲁⲃⲱⲕ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ·
Translation: and I would find Him in the place whither I am going.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲉⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲉⲡⲏⲓ ⲛⲛⲉϥⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And he came to the house of his parents,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥϫⲱ ⲉⲣⲟⲟⲩ ⲛⲟⲩⲗⲟⲓϭⲉ ⲛϯⲙⲓⲛⲉ ⲉϥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲁⲛⲁⲩ ⲱ ⲛⲁⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ · ϫⲉⲁⲛⲟⲕ ϯϣⲟⲟⲡ ϩⲛⲟⲩϣⲓⲛⲉ ⲛⲧⲙⲏⲧⲉ ⲛⲛⲁϣⲃⲏⲣⲥⲭⲟⲗⲁⲥⲧⲓⲕⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲥⲉϣⲟⲟⲡ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲥⲭⲟⲗⲏ ⲉⲣⲉⲟⲩⲉⲩⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲓⲟⲛ ⲛⲛⲟⲩⲃ ⲛⲧⲟⲟⲧϥ ⲙⲡⲟⲩⲁ ⲡⲟⲩⲁ ⲛⲧⲁⲛⲉⲩⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ ⲥⲙⲛⲧϥ ⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲩⲱϣ ϩⲓⲱⲱϥ ·
Translation: and he told them the reason [for his desire], and he spake unto them thus: 'Behold, O my parents, I am put to shame among my fellow scholars, for of all those who are at school with me each one hath his own Gospel of gold, which their parents have prepared for them to read in.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲇⲉ ϩⲱ ⲉⲓⲟ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲟⲩϩⲏⲕⲉ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲩⲙⲏⲏⲧⲉ ⲉⲙⲛⲧϥⲉⲓⲱⲧ ⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲏ ⲙⲁⲁⲩ ·
Translation: As for me I am like a beggar in their midst, and like one who hath neither father nor mother.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲉⲥⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲇⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲧⲉϥⲙⲁⲁⲩ ⲁⲥⲣⲁϣⲉ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ϫⲉⲛⲉⲥⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲡⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉϥⲧⲥⲁⲃⲟ ⲕⲁⲗⲱⲥ ·
Translation: And when his mother heard [these words] she rejoiced exceedingly, for it was her wish that he should be well instructed.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲉⲧⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲉⲥⲉⲓⲣⲉ ϩⲓⲛⲁⲓ ⲁⲥϣⲁϫⲉ ⲙⲛⲡⲉⲥϩⲁⲓ ⲉⲥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲛⲥⲟⲛ ⲧⲁⲙⲓⲟ ⲛⲟⲩⲉⲩⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲓⲟⲛ ⲛⲛⲟⲩⲃ ⲙⲡⲉⲛϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ·
Translation: And when she had thought over these things she spake unto her husband, saying, 'My lord brother, make a Gospel of gold for our son John.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩⲙⲟⲛⲟⲛ ϫⲉⲥϩⲁⲓϥ ⲙⲙⲁⲧⲉ ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲕⲟⲥⲙⲉⲓ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ⲕⲁⲗⲱⲥ ϩⲛϩⲉⲛⲱⲛⲉ ⲙⲙⲉ · ⲉⲛⲁϣⲉⲥⲟⲩⲛⲧⲟⲩ ·
Translation: Do not have it beautifully written only, but decorate it also beautifully with really precious stones of great value.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ϩⲛⲧⲉⲩⲛⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲁϥⲟⲩⲉϩⲥⲁϩⲛⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲉϥⲉⲓⲱⲧ ·
Translation: And straightway his father commanded,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲉⲓⲛⲉ ⲛⲁϥ ⲛϯⲟⲩ ⲛϣⲉ ⲛϩⲟⲗⲟⲕⲟⲧⲧⲓⲛⲟⲥ ⲙⲛϩⲉⲛⲱⲛⲉ ⲙⲙⲉ · ⲉⲩⲧⲁⲓⲏⲩ ⲁϥⲧⲁⲁⲩ ⲛⲟⲩⲥⲁϩ · ⲛϩⲁⲩⲛⲟⲩⲃ ·
Translation: and one brought to him five hundred holokottinoi (oboli) and precious stones of great beauty, and he gave them to a cunning goldsmith,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲧⲁⲙⲓⲟ ⲛⲁϥ ⲛⲧⲕⲟⲥⲙⲏⲥⲓⲥ ⲛⲟⲩⲉⲩⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲓⲟⲛ ⲛⲧⲁⲩⲥⲁϩϥ ·
Translation: and he made for him very beautiful decorations for the Gospel which he had caused to be written.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁⲡⲉϥⲉⲓⲱⲧ ϫⲓⲧϥ ⲁϥⲧⲁⲁϥ ⲛⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲡⲉϥϣⲏⲣⲉ ·
Translation: And John's father took it and gave it to his son,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥϫⲓⲧϥ ϫⲉⲛϭⲓⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲁϥⲣⲁϣⲉ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲉϫⲱϥ ·
Translation: and John took it, and rejoiced over it,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛϥϫⲓⲥⲃⲱ ϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲛϩⲏⲧϥ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲙⲕⲁϩ ⲛϩⲏⲧ ·
Translation: and he studied it with great diligence.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛϥϭⲱϣⲧ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲏⲧϥ ⲙⲡⲥⲟⲛ ⲙⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ϣⲁⲛⲧϥⲉⲓ ⲛϥⲃⲱⲕ ⲛⲙⲙⲁϥ ⁛—
Translation: And he waited for that brother who was a monk to come in order to depart with him;

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲣϥⲛⲁⲩ ⲇⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲉⲡⲥⲟⲛ ⲡⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲁϥⲣⲁϣⲉ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁϥⲧⲉⲗⲏⲗ ⲁϥⲁⲥⲡⲁⲍⲉ ⲙⲙⲟϥ · ⲉϥϣⲟⲟⲡ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲣⲁϣⲉ ·
Translation: And when John saw the brother who was a monk he rejoiced exceedingly, and was glad, and he saluted him, and he was in a state of great joy.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲛⲉⲓⲱⲧ ϯⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲡⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲛⲛⲁⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ · ⲙⲛⲡⲉⲩⲙⲉ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲣⲟⲓ ·
Translation: And he said unto him, 'My lord father, I know the wishes of my parents, and their love towards me,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲙⲁⲗⲓⲥⲧⲁ ⲧⲁⲙⲁⲁⲩ ⲛϩⲟⲩⲟ ⲉϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲉⲥϣⲁⲛⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲉϩⲱⲃ ⲛϯⲙⲓⲛⲉ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲣⲟⲓ · ϣⲁⲣⲉⲛⲉⲥⲣⲙⲉⲓⲟⲟⲩⲉ ϯϩⲓⲥⲉ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲉⲡⲉϩⲟⲩⲟ ·
Translation: and especially the wish and love of my mother. If she were to hear of such a thing as this in connection with me she would weep, and suffer greatly because of me.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ϯⲥⲟⲡⲥⲡ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ⲙⲁⲣⲛϩⲉ ⲉⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲧⲛⲃⲱⲕ ⲛⲁⲛ ⲛϫⲓⲟⲩⲉ ·
Translation: I therefore beseech thee to let us arrange that we go away secretly,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲙⲡⲣⲧⲣⲉⲗⲁⲁⲩ ⲉⲓⲙⲉ · ⲉⲡⲉⲛϫⲱⲕ ·
Translation: and not to let any one know of our departure.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲡⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲁⲛⲁⲕ ϯⲛⲁⲁⲥ ⲛⲙⲙⲁⲕ ·
Translation: And the monk said unto him, 'Whatsoever pleaseth thee that will I do with thee,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ⲇⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲙⲛⲡⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ·
Translation: And John and the monk rose up,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲃⲱⲕ ⲛⲁⲩ ⲛϫⲓⲟⲩⲉ ·
Translation: and they departed secretly.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲉⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲉϫⲛⲧϩⲁⲗⲗⲁⲥⲁ · ⲉⲩϣⲓⲛⲉ ⲛⲥⲁⲟⲩϫⲟⲓ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲩⲁⲗⲉ
Translation: And they arrived at the sea, and they searched for a boat wherein to embark.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲧⲟⲧⲉ ⲡⲉϫⲉⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉϯⲛⲁⲧⲁⲁⲩ ⲛⲁⲕ ·
Translation: Then John said unto him, 'I will give them to thee';

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ
Translation: and when John had said this he came to the place where was the brother who was a monk,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉⲡⲁⲉⲓⲱⲧ
Translation: and he said unto him, 'My father, the ship's fare is large, and it is meet for thee that we should depart quickly, lest some people meet us, and they recognize us, and they seize us, and we be put to shame. Therefore, let us flee secretly.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲧⲟⲧⲉ ⲁϥⲃⲱⲕ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ
Translation: Then John went into his house to his mother,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁⲥ ϫⲉϯⲥⲟⲡⲥⲡ
Translation: and he said unto her, 'I make entreaty unto thee, O my beloved mother. I know well that thou fulfillest all my wishes,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲕⲉⲟⲩⲁ
Translation: but there is one thing that I lack, [and which if granted] would cause us both to be praised.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲟⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲡⲉϫⲁⲥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉϩⲱⲃ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲉⲧⲕⲟⲩⲁϣϥ
Translation: And she said unto him, 'Whatsoever thou wishest ask at my hand, my son, and I will fulfill thy desire for thee.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲛⲧⲉϥⲙⲁⲁⲩ
Translation: And John said unto his mother, 'Thou knowest that all the youths who are with me at school have provided me with meals, and that not once, nor twice, and that I have eaten often of their provisions.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ
Translation: Now there is nothing at all which I can do for them in return for what they have given unto me,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲙⲡϣⲓⲡⲉ
Translation: and I am in truth ashamed to enter the school again because of this matter.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲧⲉϥⲙⲁⲁⲩ ⲛⲁϥ · ϫⲉⲡⲉⲧⲉⲕⲟⲩⲁϣϥ
Translation: His mother saith unto him, 'Whatsoever thou wishest I will do for thee.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲉⲣϣⲁⲛⲡⲉⲕⲉⲓⲱⲧ
Translation: When thy father cometh into the house at the hour of noon I will make him to give it (i.e., money) to thee, so that thou and thy companions mayest do what thou wishest therewith.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲟϥ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥⲟⲩⲱϣⲃ ·
Translation: And his father answered and said, 'I will give unto him everything that he wisheth for,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁⲩⲧⲉϣⲡϩⲙϩⲁⲗ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ·
Translation: and appointed a servant to attend him.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲣϥϫⲓ ⲛⲛⲛⲟⲩⲃ
Translation: And when John had taken the money he went to the place wherein was the monk, both he and the servant who accompanied him, and he said unto the monk, 'My lord brother, this servant whom thou seest belongeth to me.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲣⲓⲧⲁⲅⲁⲡⲏ ⲛⲅⲕⲁⲁϥ ϩⲁϩⲧⲏⲕ
Translation: I beseech thee to do me an act of grace, and let him tarry with thee, whilst I go to the place where some neighbours of mine are to enquire concerning a certain person who was coming to me at this hour.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲧⲟⲧⲉ ⲁϥⲉⲓⲙⲉ
Translation: Then the old man, the monk, understood that he was talking to him concerning the captain of the ship,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲛⲧⲁϥⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲉⲡⲟⲟⲛϥ
Translation: and that he wished to go away by himself by reason of the servant who accompanied him.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥϫⲓ
Translation: And John took the hundred oboli, and came to the place of the captain of the ship,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉϯⲥⲟⲡⲥⲡ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ
Translation: I beseech thee, O my lord brother, to make ready to sail, and let us depart quickly, I and my brother.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲛⲉⲉϥ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲣϥⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲉⲛⲁⲓ ϫⲉⲉϥⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲉⲃⲱⲕ ⲛⲁϥ ⲛϫⲓⲟⲩⲉ · ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲛⲉⲉϥ ϫⲉⲁⲓⲟⲩⲱ ⲉⲓⲥⲟⲃⲧⲉ ⲙⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁⲓⲟⲩⲱ ⲉⲓϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲕ ⲛⲕⲉⲥⲟⲡ ϫⲉⲧϩⲏⲙⲉ ⲙⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓ ⲟⲩⲛⲟϭ ⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And when the captain heard this, [and knew] that he wished to depart secretly, he said unto him, 'I have already finished making my ship ready to sail, and I have already told you that the passage money by my ship is high.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲉϣⲱⲡⲉ ϣⲁⲕϭⲱ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ · ϣⲁⲛⲧⲁⲧⲁⲗⲉⲡⲁⲩⲉⲓⲛ ⲉⲡϫⲟⲉⲓ ϣⲁⲓⲧⲁⲗⲟⲧⲛ ·
Translation: However, if thou wilt remain in this place until I have loaded up my vessel, I will embark thee.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ϫⲉⲁⲓⲟⲩⲱ ⲉⲓϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲕ ϫⲉϣⲁⲓϯⲧϩⲏⲙⲉ ⲛⲁⲕ ⲕⲁⲧⲁⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲕϫⲟⲟⲥ ·
Translation: And John said, 'I have already told thee that I will give thee the passage money, according to what thou didst say.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲩⲛⲟⲩ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥⲉⲓⲛⲉ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲙⲡϣⲉ ⲛϩⲟⲗⲟⲕⲟⲧⲧⲓⲛⲟⲥ ⲛⲧⲟⲟⲧϥ ⲉϥⲣⲁϣⲉ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And straightway he brought out the hundred oboli in his hand, rejoicing greatly,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲧⲁⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ ⲉϥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ · ϫⲉ
Translation: and he gave them to him, saying, 'Whatsoever thou informest me [is needed] more than these I will give unto thee.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲛⲉⲉϥ ⲇⲉ ⲙⲡϫⲟⲉⲓ ⲛⲧⲉⲣϥⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲉⲛⲁⲓ · ⲁϥϫⲓ ⲙⲡϣⲉ ⲛϩⲟⲗⲟⲕⲟⲧⲧⲓⲛⲟⲥ ⲛⲧⲟⲟⲧϥ ⲉϥⲣⲁϣⲉ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And when the captain of the ship heard these words he took the hundred oboli in his hand, and rejoiced exceedingly,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ · ϫⲉⲃⲱⲕ ⲁⲛⲓⲡⲉⲕϣⲃⲏⲣ ⲛⲅⲉⲓ ·
Translation: and he said unto John, 'Go and bring thy companion, and come [back];

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲉϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲡⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲡⲉ ϯⲛⲁϥⲓ ⲙⲡⲉⲧⲛⲣⲟⲟⲩϣ ⲕⲁⲗⲱⲥ ·
Translation: if it be the will of God I will take most excellent care of you.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲕⲟⲧϥ ⲛϭⲓⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ·
Translation: And John returned,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲧⲁⲙⲉⲡⲥⲟⲛ ⲙⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲉϩⲱⲃ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲛⲧⲁϥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ·
Translation: and informed the brother who was a monk about everything that had happened unto him.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲁⲕⲉϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲇⲉ ⲥⲛⲁⲩ ⲡⲉϫⲉⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲙⲡⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ · ϫⲉⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ⲛⲧⲛⲃⲱⲕ ⲉϫⲛⲧϩⲁⲗⲗⲁⲥⲁ · ⲉⲡⲉⲓⲇⲏ ⲡⲁⲓ ⲡⲉ ⲡⲉϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲓⲛⲁⲥⲃⲧⲉⲡⲁⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲛ ⲉⲛⲁϣⲃⲏⲣ ·
Translation: And after two days John said unto the monk, 'Rise up, and let us depart by sea, because this is the day whereon I ought to make ready the meal for my fellow learners,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲉⲓⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲉⲕⲱⲧⲉ ⲛⲥⲁⲟⲩϣⲏⲙ ⲛⲧⲃⲧ ⲛⲁⲩ ·
Translation: and I ought to seek for some small fish for them.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲉⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲉϫⲛⲧϩⲁⲗⲗⲁⲥⲁ ϩⲙⲡⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And they came to the sea-shore by the will of God,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲉⲓ ⲛϭⲓⲟⲩⲧⲏⲩ ⲉⲛⲁⲛⲟⲩϥ ·
Translation: and a favorable wind arose,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲃⲱⲕ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲛⲉⲉϥ
Translation: and the captain embarked on the ship, and stood on the side of it,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ ⲁϥϫⲱⲣⲙ ⲟⲩⲃⲉⲓⲱⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲙⲛⲡⲕⲉⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ
Translation: and he stooped down and beckoned to John and the monk, saying, 'Arise come ye and embark.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲉⲛⲉⲩϣⲧⲣⲧⲱⲣ
Translation: Now they were troubled, for they wished to send away the servant from them, and to leave him behind,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲙⲡⲟⲩϭⲛⲧϩⲉ ·
Translation: but they could not find any satisfactory means for doing so.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲙⲡϩⲙϩⲁⲗ
Translation: And John said unto the servant who was accompanying him, 'Rise up and go to the palace, to the scholars, and see if they have all assembled there, and then come back quickly and let me know;

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲉⲓⲥϩⲏⲏⲧⲉ ϯϭⲱϣⲧ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲏⲧⲕ ·
Translation: behold, I will wait for thee here';

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲃⲱⲕ ⲇⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲡϩⲙϩⲁⲗ
Translation: and the servant departed.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲟⲟⲩ ⲇⲉ ϩⲱⲟⲩ ⲁⲩⲧⲁⲗⲟⲟⲩ ⲛⲧⲉⲩⲛⲟⲩ ⲁⲩϭⲉⲩⲡϫⲟⲉⲓ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ
Translation: And they themselves went up into the ship, which set sail at once,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲉⲓ ⲉⲧⲙⲟⲛⲏ ϩⲙⲡⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: and they arrived at the monastery by the will of God.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲕⲧⲟϥ ⲇⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲡϩⲙϩⲁⲗ ⲉϫⲛⲧϩⲁⲗⲗⲁⲥⲁ ⲙⲡⲉϥϩⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲟⲩ
Translation: And the servant returned to the sea-shore and did not find them,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥϣⲧⲟⲣⲧⲣ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ϩⲙⲡⲉϥϩⲏⲧ ϫⲉⲁⲣⲁ ⲧⲁⲡⲱⲧ ⲛⲧⲁⲧⲙⲧⲁⲙⲉⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ
Translation: and he was disturbed exceedingly in his mind, saying, 'Shall I take to flight and not tell my master?'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲉⲓⲧⲁ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲟⲛ ϫⲉⲉⲓⲣϩⲟⲧⲉ ⲙⲏⲡⲟⲧⲉ ⲛⲥⲉⲕⲱⲧⲉ ⲛⲥⲱⲓ
Translation: Then he said, 'I am afraid that they will make search for me and that they will find me, and inflict many evils upon me;

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲉⲥⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲇⲉ ⲉⲛⲁⲓ ⲛϭⲓⲧⲉϥⲙⲁⲁⲩ ⲁⲥⲡⲱϩ ⲛⲛⲉⲥϩⲟⲓⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And it came to pass that when his mother heard these things she rent her garments,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁⲥⲧⲁⲗⲉⲉⲓⲁⲧⲛ ⲉϫⲛⲧⲉⲥⲁⲡⲉ ·
Translation: and she scattered dust upon her head,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲥⲣⲓⲙⲉ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲣⲓⲙⲉ · ⲉⲥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲡⲁⲙⲉⲣⲓⲧ ⲛϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ·
Translation: and she wept with a great weeping, saying, 'Woe is me, O my beloved son John!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩ ⲡⲉⲛⲧⲁϥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲧϩⲟⲗϭ ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ϫⲉⲁⲩϣⲟⲛⲧ ⲉⲡⲉⲕϩⲟ ⲱ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲙⲙⲉⲣⲓⲧ ·
Translation: What hath become of thee, O my sweet son? Woe is me, O my son! For thy face is . . . . . . . . . O John, my beloved son!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ
Translation: Woe is me!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲓⲙ ⲡⲉ ⲛⲧⲁϥϥⲓ ⲙⲡⲁϩⲏⲃⲥ ⲛϩⲏⲧ ·
Translation: Who hath carried away the light of my body?

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛϯⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ
Translation: I know not.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ
Translation: Woe is me!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲓⲙ ⲡⲉ ⲛⲧⲁϥϥⲓ ⲙⲡⲁⲙⲉⲣⲓⲧ ⲛϣⲏⲣⲉ
Translation: Who hath carried away my beloved son, the darling of my soul?

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲱ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲙⲙⲉⲣⲓⲧ ·
Translation: O John, my beloved son!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲱ ⲡⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓⲛ ⲛⲛⲁⲃⲁⲗ ·
Translation: O light of mine eyes!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲓϫⲟⲟⲩⲕ ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲟⲩⲥⲟⲫⲓⲁ · ⲙⲡⲉⲓϩⲉ ⲉⲡⲧⲱϣ ⲛⲧⲁϥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ
Translation: Why did I send thee forth after wisdom in this manner [to meet] the fate which hath come upon thee?

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲉⲧϩⲟⲗϭ ⲛⲛⲁϩⲣⲛⲟⲩⲟⲛ ⲛⲓⲙ ·
Translation: Woe be unto me, o my son, who was sweet to everyone!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲉⲧϩⲟⲗϭ ⲡⲁⲡⲉⲓϩⲟ ⲉⲧⲙⲉϩ ⲛⲣⲁϣⲉ ⲛⲓⲙ ·
Translation: Woe be unto me, my son, my sweet one, thou face full of joy!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲡⲁⲧⲧϩⲓⲕⲱⲛ ⲛⲛⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ·
Translation: Woe unto me, thou who resemblest the angels!

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲱ ⲡⲉⲧⲓⲛⲁⲁⲁϥ
Translation: Woe unto me! What shall I do from this day henceforth?'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲓϩⲉ ⲇⲉ ⲟⲛ ⲡⲉϥⲕⲉⲉⲓⲱⲧ
Translation: And thus also did his father weep, with groanings, and sighings, and sorrow of heart, and he cried out, saying, What hath happened unto thee, O my beloved son?

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛϯⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ
Translation: I know not what hath happened unto thee suddenly.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲟⲩϫⲱⲕ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲥⲁϣϥ ⲛϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲛϩⲏⲃⲉ · ⲉⲣⲉⲧⲡⲟⲗⲓⲥ ⲧⲏⲣⲥ ⲣϩⲏⲃⲉ ⲛⲙⲙⲁⲩ ·
Translation: And whilst the seven days of weeping were being fulfilled the whole city mourned with them.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲧⲟⲧⲉ ⲡⲉϥⲉⲓⲱⲧ ⲁϥⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ⲁϥⲃⲱⲕ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲡⲡⲁⲗⲗⲁϯⲟⲛ ⲁϥⲧⲁⲙⲉⲡⲣⲣⲟ ⲉϩⲱⲃ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲛⲧⲁⲩϣⲱⲡⲉ ·
Translation: Then his father rose up and went into the palace, and informed the king of everything which had happened,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁϥⲡⲁⲣⲁⲕⲁⲗⲉⲓ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ⲉⲧⲣⲉϥⲧⲛⲛⲟⲟⲩ ⲛⲟⲩⲕⲉⲗⲉⲩⲥⲓⲥ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲙⲙⲁ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲛⲧⲉⲧⲉϥⲙⲛⲧⲣⲣⲟ ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲩⲉϣⲓⲛⲉ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧϥ ⲙⲉϣⲁⲕ ⲛⲥⲉϩⲉ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ·
Translation: and he entreated him to send out an order to every part of his kingdom, so that the people might seek for his son, and, peradventure, might find him.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲉϥⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲟⲩϩⲓⲥⲉ ⲉⲩⲕⲱⲧⲉ ⲛⲥⲱϥ ⲙⲡⲟⲩϩⲉ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ⲁⲩϯⲉⲟⲟⲩ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And [although] his parents have worn themselves out in going round about without finding him they ascribed glory to God.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥⲉⲓ ⲡⲙⲟⲛⲁⲥⲧⲏⲣⲓⲟⲛ ⲛⲧⲟϥ ⲙⲛⲡⲕⲉⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲉⲧⲙⲟⲟϣⲉ ⲛⲙⲙⲁϥ ·
Translation: And John came to the monastery, he and the monk also who accompanied him,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥϥⲓ ⲙⲡⲉⲩⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲓⲟⲛ ⲛⲛⲟⲩⲃ ⲛⲙⲙⲁϥ ⲡⲁⲓ ⲛⲧⲁⲛⲉϥⲉⲓⲟⲧⲉ ⲥⲙⲛⲧϥ ⲛⲁϥ ·
Translation: and he carried with him the Gospel of gold which his parents had made for him,

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲧⲁⲙⲉⲡⲣⲟⲉⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ⲉϩⲱⲃ ⲛⲓⲙ · ⲛⲧⲁϥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲙⲡϣⲏⲣⲉ ϣⲏⲙ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ · ⲙⲛⲧⲉϥⲛⲟϭ ⲙⲡⲓⲥⲧⲓⲥ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: and he (i.e., the monk) informed the head of the monastery of everything which had happened to the young man John, and about his great belief in God.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲁⲣⲭⲓⲙⲁⲛⲇⲣⲓⲧⲏⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲙⲡϣⲏⲣⲉ ϣⲏⲙ ϫⲉⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲉⲓⲥϩⲏⲏⲧⲉ ϯⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ϫⲉⲛⲧⲕⲟⲩⲕⲟⲩⲓ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲕϭⲟⲧ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛⲥⲁⲓⲉ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ϩⲛⲛⲉⲕϩⲃⲏⲩⲉ :—
Translation: And the Archimandrite said unto the young man, 'My son, behold, I see that thou art young in years, but exceedingly well-doing in thy works.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲗⲟⲓⲡⲟⲛ ⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲟⲩⲟⲛ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲉⲧⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲉⲁⲡⲟⲧⲁⲥⲥⲉ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲕⲟⲥⲙⲟⲥ ⲉⲩⲟ ⲛⲧⲉⲕϭⲟⲧ ϣⲁⲩⲣϩⲙⲉ ⲛϩⲟⲟⲩ · ⲉⲩϩⲩⲡⲟⲙⲉⲓⲛⲉ ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲱⲥ ϣⲁⲩϣⲃⲡϥⲱ ⲛⲧⲉⲩⲁⲡⲉ · ⲛⲥⲉϯⲥⲭⲏⲙⲁ ⲉϫⲱⲟⲩ ·
Translation: Moreover, my son, every one who wisheth to withdraw himself from this world, if he be of thine age, waiteth patiently for forty days, and after that period the hair of his head is shaved off, and then he assumeth the garb of the monk.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉϯⲧⲁⲣⲕⲟ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ⲡⲁⲉⲓⲱⲧ ⲉⲧⲟⲩⲁⲁⲃ ⲛⲧⲉⲧⲣⲓⲁⲥ ⲉⲧⲟⲩⲁⲁⲃ ⲛϩⲟⲙⲟⲟⲩⲥⲓⲟⲛ ⲙⲛⲛⲉϣⲗⲏⲗ ⲙⲡⲙⲟⲛⲁⲥⲧⲏⲣⲓⲟⲛ ⲉⲕⲉϣⲃϫⲱⲓ ⲙⲡϩⲟⲟⲩ · ⲉⲡⲉⲓⲇⲏ ⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲡⲉⲧⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ ϫⲉⲡⲁϩⲏⲧ ⲙⲟⲕϩ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲧⲙⲛⲧⲙⲟⲛⲁⲭⲟⲥ ⲙⲛⲡⲉⲥⲭⲏⲙⲁ ⲛⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲓⲕⲟⲛ ·
Translation: And John said unto him, 'I adjure thee, O my holy father, by the Holy and Consubstantial Trinity, and by the prayers of the monastery, that thou shave my head this day, and especially, as God knoweth, my heart burneth with desire for the life of the monk, and for the garb of the angels.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲁⲣⲭⲓⲙⲁⲛⲇⲣⲓⲧⲏⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥⲡⲉⲓⲑⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲩⲛⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲣⲉϥϣⲗⲏⲗ ⲉϫⲱϥ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁϥϯ ⲉϫⲱϥ ⲙⲡⲉⲥⲭⲏⲙⲁ ⲛⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲓⲕⲟⲛ ·
Translation: And the Archimandrite was persuaded, and straightway he prayed over him, and he placed upon him the angelic garb.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲟϥ ⲇⲉ ⲁⲡⲉϥϩⲏⲧ ⲟⲩⲛⲟϥ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛϥⲧⲱⲃϩ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲙⲡⲉϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲙⲛⲧⲉⲩϣⲏ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲛⲟϭ ⲛϫⲱⲗⲕ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲱⲥⲧⲉ ⲛⲉϥϣⲗⲏⲗ ⲙⲛⲛⲉϥⲡⲟⲗⲓⲧⲉⲓⲁ · ⲙⲛⲛⲉϥⲁⲥⲕⲏⲥⲓⲥ · ⲛⲥⲉⲣⲛⲟϭ
Translation: And the heart of John rejoiced within him exceedingly, and he prayed to God by day and by night with such exceedingly long prayers that his praying, and his daily contest, and his asceticism were far in excess of a very great many of those who were his neighbours.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲁϥⲣϩⲉⲛⲛⲟϭ ⲙⲡⲟⲗⲓⲧⲉⲓⲁ ⲙⲛϩⲉⲛⲁⲥⲕⲏⲥⲓⲥ ⲉⲛⲁϣⲱⲟⲩ ·
Translation: and besides this he engaged in many contests of self-abnegation, and practised many habits of self-repression.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲁϥⲛⲁⲩ ⲇⲉ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲁⲣⲭⲏⲙⲁⲛⲧⲣⲓⲧⲏⲥ ⲁϥⲣϣⲡⲏⲣⲉ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ·
Translation: And the Archimandrite saw him, and marvelled exceedingly.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲡⲁⲣⲭⲓⲙⲁⲛⲇⲣⲓⲧⲏⲥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲛⲧⲕⲟⲩϣⲏⲣⲉ ϣⲏⲙ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲉⲓⲥϩⲏⲏⲧⲉ ϯⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ⲉⲕⲉⲓⲣⲉ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲁⲥⲕⲏⲥⲓⲥ ⲉⲛⲁϣⲱⲟⲩ ⲉⲕⲙⲟⲩⲟⲩⲧ ⲙⲡⲉⲕⲥⲱⲙⲁ ⲙⲙⲓⲛⲙⲙⲟⲕ ϩⲱⲥⲧⲉ ⲛⲅⲧⲙⲉϣⲁϩⲉⲣⲁⲧⲕ ⲉⲡⲉϣⲗⲏⲗ · ⲙⲛⲧⲛⲏⲥⲧⲉⲓⲁ ·
Translation: And the Archimandrite said unto him, 'My son, thou art a very young man, but behold, I see thee practising very many mighty works of abstinence; thou wilt thyself destroy thine own body, and wilt not be able to stand up, neither to pray, nor to fast.

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲡⲣⲱϣⲉ ⲛⲉⲅⲕⲣⲁⲧⲉⲓⲁ ϣⲁⲩⲣⲡⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲛϭⲱⲃ ⲉⲡⲉϩⲟⲩⲟ ·
Translation: For overmuch ascetic labour exhausteth a man greatly, and maketh him weak.'

Book Name: The Life of John the Kalybites part 1
Verse: ⲛⲧⲟϥ ⲇⲉ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲙⲡⲉϥⲕⲁⲧⲟⲟⲧϥ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲛⲙⲡⲟⲗⲓⲧⲉⲓⲁ · ⲉⲛⲉϥⲉⲓⲣⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ
Translation: But John did not cease to practise the labours which he had begun to perform.

Book Name: Mysteries of John the Evangelist part 2
Verse: ▢ ⲁⲓⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ⲇⲉ ⲁⲓⲟⲩⲁϩⲧ ⲛⲥⲱϥ ⲁⲓⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ⲁⲓⲟⲩⲁϩⲧ ⲛⲥⲱϥ
Translation: I rose up and I followed him.

Book Name: Mysteries of John the Evangelist part 2

Verse: ⲁⲥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲇⲉ
Translation: and it came to pass that as they were praying the ten fingers of Jesus became ten lamps of fire which penetrated to the throne of the Father.

Verse: ⲁⲥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲟⲩⲟⲩⲱ ⲉⲩϣⲗⲏⲗ · ⲁϥϯⲡⲉϥⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲁϥⲁⲥⲡⲁⲍⲉ ⲛⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ · ⲛⲉϥⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ ⲁⲛ ϫⲉⲛⲓⲙ ⲡⲉ · ⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲇⲉ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ ·
Translation: And it came to pass that when they had finished praying Apa Victor went forward and saluted Jesus — now he knew not who lie was — and he said unto Him

Verse: ϫⲉϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲕ ⲛⲧⲁⲥⲉⲓ ⲙⲡⲉⲕϩⲟ ϫⲉⲉⲓⲥⲟⲩⲙⲏⲏϣⲉ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓϣ ⲙⲡⲓⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲣⲱⲙⲉ · ⲁⲩⲱ ϯⲱⲣⲕ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲕⲉⲧⲁⲙⲟⲓ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲱⲣϫ ϫⲉⲛⲧⲕⲟⲩⲣⲙⲧⲱⲛ · ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲓⲉⲉⲓⲙⲉ ϫⲉⲛⲧⲕⲟⲩⲣⲙⲧⲁⲡⲟⲗⲓⲥ ·
Translation: Sit Thou down so that I may be able to enjoy thy face fully, for behold, it is a very long time since I have seen a man. And I adjure Thee to inform me truthfully of what place Thou art a native, so that I may know whether Thou art a native of my own city (or not)

Verse: ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ ·
Translation: And Jesus said unto Him,

Verse: ϫⲉⲛⲧⲕⲟⲩⲣⲙϩⲣⲱⲙⲏ ⲛⲧⲕⲓⲗⲓⲕⲓⲁ
Translation: Thou art a Roman (Greek?) of Cilicia.

Verse: ϩⲣⲱⲙⲁⲛⲟⲥ ⲡⲉ ⲡⲉⲕⲉⲓⲱⲧ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲙⲁⲣⲑⲁ
Translation: Thy father is Romanus and thy mother is Martha, and the wife whom they betrothed to thee is Theonoe; but God hath chosen thee for Himself

Verse: ⲁⲡⲁ
Translation: And Apa Victor wept in His face, and said unto Him,

Verse: ϫⲉⲟ
Translation: O my brother, great is Thy faith.

Verse: ϯⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ϫⲉⲛⲧⲕⲟⲩⲡⲣⲟⲫⲏⲧⲏⲥ
Translation: I see that Thou art a prophet, or perhaps Thou art an angel of God.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲧⲁⲙⲟⲓ ⲇⲉ ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲏⲓ · ϫⲉⲉⲓⲥⲟⲩⲏⲣ
Translation: But tell me news about my house (or, home), for behold, it is a very long time since I departed from my country.

Verse: ⲁϥⲟⲩⲱϣⲃ ⲛϭⲓⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ
Translation: And Jesus answered (and said)

Verse: ϫⲉⲱ ⲡⲁⲥⲟⲛ ⲁⲣⲓⲟⲩⲙⲛⲧⲙⲁⲓ
Translation: O my brother, shew an act of lovingkindness to me, and give me a cake of bread, so that I may eat it, for it is seven days since I ate food.

Verse: ⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲇⲉ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ·
Translation: And Apa Victor said unto Him

Verse: ϫⲉϩⲛⲟⲩⲙⲉ ⲡⲁⲥⲟⲛ ⲡⲁⲙⲉϩϩⲙⲉ
Translation: In truth, O my brother, this day is the fortieth day in which nothing hath entered my mouth, and for forty days I have not taken my clothes off my body.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ϥⲟⲛϩ ⲛϭⲓⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ · ϫⲉⲙⲛⲟⲉⲓⲕ ⲟⲩⲇⲉ
Translation: And as the Lord liveth I have neither bread nor water in this wilderness, nor anything whatsoever which hath the appearance of food.

Verse: ⲧⲉⲛⲟⲩ ϭⲉ ⲡⲁⲥⲟⲛ ⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ⲛⲅϫⲓ
Translation: But now, O my brother, rise up, take this lamp-stand and these seats (or, stools), and also my shoe latchet, and go Thou into the city which is near and sell them at their (proper) price, and buy us some bread that we may eat, lest our souls decay through weakness.

Verse: ⲁϥⲟⲩⲱϣⲃ ⲛϭⲓⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ϫⲉϣⲁⲕϩⲉ ⲉⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲧⲱⲛ ⲛⲅϣⲁϫⲉ ⲛⲙⲙⲁϥ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲓⲉⲣⲏⲙⲓⲁ · ⲏ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲡⲉϣⲁϥϥⲓⲡⲣⲟⲟⲩϣ ⲛⲧⲉⲕⲧⲣⲟⲫⲏ ·
Translation: And Jesus answered and said unto him, 'Where in this wilderness dost thou find a man with whom to hold converse? And who is it that taketh care to provide thee with food?

Verse: ⲁϥⲟⲩⲱϣⲃ ⲛϭⲓⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ
Translation: And Apa Victor answered and said unto Him,

Verse: ϫⲉⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲡⲁⲥⲟⲛ · ⲙⲡⲁⲧⲓⲡⲱϩ ⲉⲡⲕⲉⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲉⲙⲛϫⲓϩⲟ ⲛϩⲏⲧϥ · ⲛⲅϩⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲥ ⲉⲣⲉⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ · ⲉⲣⲉⲛⲁⲡⲟⲥⲧⲟⲗⲟⲥ ⲙⲛⲙⲡⲁⲧⲣⲓⲁⲣⲭⲏⲥ ϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ · ⲉⲣⲉϩⲉⲛϣⲟ ⲛϣⲟ ⲙⲛϩⲉⲛⲧⲃⲁ ⲛⲧⲃⲁ ⲛⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ⲁⲁϩⲉⲣⲁⲧⲟⲩ ⲙⲡⲉϥⲕⲱⲧⲉ ·
Translation: Woe be unto me, O my brother! (Long will it be) before I shall arrive in that other world wherein no respect of persons is shewn. Mayest Thou find it. My Lord the Christ dwelleth there, the Apostles and the Patriarchs dwell there, and thousands of thousands, and tens of thousands of tens of thousands stand round about it.

Verse: ⲉϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲟⲩⲣⲉϥⲣⲛⲟⲃⲉ ⲡⲉ ⲟⲩⲁ · ⲉϥϣⲁⲛⲡⲱϩ ⲉⲡⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲙⲛⲧⲉϥⲡⲁⲣϩⲏⲥⲓⲁ ⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲛⲛⲟⲃⲉ ⲛⲧⲁϥⲁⲁⲩ · ⲛⲁⲡⲉϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲙⲛⲛⲁⲧⲉⲩϣⲏ ·
Translation: And if any man who is a sinner shall arrive therein lie shall not find boldness (or, freedom of speech) therein, because of the sins which he hath committed, both those committed during the day and those committed during the night

Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲡⲉ ⲡⲧⲁⲗⲁⲓⲡⲱⲣⲟⲥ ⲙⲡⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ · ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ϫⲉⲟⲩⲟⲃϣⲥ ⲧⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲩⲕⲁⲁⲥ ϩⲓϫⲙⲡϩⲏⲧ ⲙⲡⲣⲱⲙⲉ · ⲉⲧⲙⲣⲡⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ⲙⲡⲙⲟⲩ · ϣⲁⲛⲧⲉⲧⲉⲩⲛⲟⲩ ⲙⲡⲟⲩⲁ ⲡⲟⲩⲁ ⲧⲁϩⲟϥ ⲙⲡⲁⲧϥⲉⲓⲙⲉ :—
Translation: As for me, how wretched shall I be in that hour! Woe is me, because of the ignorance which hath been set in the hearts of men, whereby each one faileth to remember death until the moment when it overtaketh him before he knoweth it!

Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ϫⲉⲁⲓⲉⲡⲓⲕⲁⲗⲉ ⲙⲡⲙⲟⲩ ⲙⲡⲉⲓϩⲉ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ·
Translation: Woe is me, for I have made supplication to death, but I have not found it.

Verse: ⲁⲓⲁⲓⲧⲉⲓ ⲛⲟⲩϣⲱⲛⲉ ⲙⲡⲉϥⲓ ⲛⲁⲓ ·
Translation: I have begged that some sickness might attack me, but it hath not done so.

Verse: ⲕⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ ⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ϫⲉϯⲁⲓⲧⲉⲓ ⲙⲡⲁⲙⲟⲩ ⲡⲁⲣⲁⲡⲁⲱⲛϩ · ϫⲉⲁⲓⲣⲁⲧⲉⲓⲱⲧ ϩⲓⲙⲁⲁⲩ ϩⲙⲡⲓⲁⲓⲱⲛ
Translation: Thou knowest, O my Lord, that I have made entreaty for my death more than for my life, for I am without father and without mother in this world.

Verse: ϯⲣⲙⲛⲧⲣⲉ ⲙⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ · ϫⲉⲉⲕϣⲁⲛⲃⲱⲕ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲓⲧⲟⲟⲧ ⲙⲡϩⲟⲟⲩ · ⲉⲕⲉⲕⲧⲟⲕ ⲟⲛ ⲛⲅϭⲙⲡⲁϣⲓⲛⲉ ·
Translation: I bear witness by my Lord Jesus the Christ, that if Thou departest from me this day, Thou shalt come back again and shalt visit me.

Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲡⲉⲓϩⲙϩⲁⲗ ⲛⲁⲧϣⲁⲩ ·
Translation: I am the servant which is unprofitable.

Verse: ⲉϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲉⲓϣⲁⲛⲙⲟⲩ ⲉⲕⲉⲧⲱⲙⲥ ⲙⲡⲁⲥⲱⲙⲁ · ⲙⲏⲡⲟⲧⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲡⲁⲥⲱⲙⲁ ϭⲱ ⲉϥⲛⲏϫ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ · ⲛⲧⲉⲧⲙⲗⲁⲁⲩ ⲛⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲣⲡⲁⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ·
Translation: When I shall die Thou shalt bury my body, lest it remain lying about in this world, wherein there is no man whatsoever who shall keep me in remembrance.

Verse: ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥϣⲛϩⲧⲏϥ ϩⲁⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲉϥⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ⲉϥⲣⲓⲙⲉ ·
Translation: Then Jesus had compassion upon Apa Victor, and He looked upon him as he wept,

Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ
Translation: and said unto him,

Verse: ϫⲉⲥⲟⲩⲱⲛⲧ ϫⲉⲁⲛⲅ ⲛⲓⲙ ·
Translation: Dost thou know Who I am?

Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲡⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲓⲛⲟⲩϩⲙ
Translation: I am he Who delivered thee from the rack of torture at Rakote.

Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲡⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲓⲛⲟⲩϩⲙ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ϩⲙⲡⲉϭⲗⲟϭ ⲙⲡⲉⲛⲓⲡⲉ ·
Translation: I am He Who delivered thee from the iron bed.

Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲡⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲓⲧⲟⲩϫⲟⲕ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲧⲱⲕ ⲛⲧⲥⲓⲟⲟⲩⲛ ·
Translation: I am He Who kept thee in safety in the furnace of the bath.

Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲡⲉ ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ⲡⲉⲧⲛⲟⲩϩⲙ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ϩⲛⲛⲉⲕⲑⲗⲓⲯⲓⲥ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ·
Translation: I am Jesus the Christ, Who delivered thee from all thy tribulations.

Verse: ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ϯϣⲟⲟⲡ ⲛⲙⲙⲁⲕ ϩⲙⲙⲁ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲉⲧⲕⲛⲁⲃⲱⲕ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ·
Translation: I will be with thee in every place whither thou shalt go.

Verse: ⲙⲡⲣⲗⲩⲡⲉⲓ ϫⲉⲕϣⲟⲟⲡ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲓⲉⲣⲏⲙⲓⲁ ·
Translation: Grieve thou not because thou art living in this wilderness.

Verse: ϩⲁⲙⲏⲛ ϯϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲕ ϫⲉⲕⲛⲁϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲛⲙⲙⲁⲓ ϩⲛⲧϩⲓⲉⲣⲟⲩⲥⲁⲗⲏⲙ ⲛⲧⲡⲉ ⲧⲁⲡⲟⲗⲓⲥ ⲙⲙⲉⲣⲓⲧ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲕⲁⲧⲁⲧϩⲉ ⲉϣⲁⲓϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ ϩⲓⲡⲁⲑⲣⲟⲛⲟⲥ ·
Translation: Amen, I say unto thee, that thou shalt be with Ale in the Jerusalem of heaven, My beloved city. And as I shall take My seat upon My throne, thou also shalt sit upon thy throne.

Verse: ⲕⲛⲁϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ ϩⲱⲱⲕ ϩⲓϫⲙⲡⲱⲕ · ⲁⲩⲱ ϯⲛⲁⲧⲣⲉⲇⲩⲣⲁⲛⲛⲟⲥ ⲛⲓⲙ · ϩⲓⲁⲣⲭⲏ ⲛⲓⲙ · ⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲉⲕⲣⲁⲛ ⲛⲥⲉⲣϣⲡⲏⲣⲉ ·
Translation: thou also shalt sit upon thy throne. And I will make every tyrant (or. governor) and every ruler to hold in wonder thy name whensoever they shall hear it.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ϯⲛⲁⲧⲣⲉⲩⲉⲓ ⲉⲣⲁⲧϥ ⲙⲡⲉⲕⲧⲟⲡⲟⲥ · ⲛⲥⲉⲛⲇⲱⲣⲟⲛ ⲛⲁⲕ ϩⲙⲡⲁⲣⲁⲛ ·
Translation: And I will make them to come to thy shrine and to bring gifts unto thee in My Name.

Verse: ϯⲛⲁⲧⲣⲉϩⲉⲛⲛⲟϭ ⲛϣⲡⲏⲣⲉ ⲙⲛϩⲉⲛⲙⲁⲉⲓⲛ ⲟⲩⲱⲛϩ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲙⲡⲉⲕⲧⲟⲡⲟⲥ ·
Translation: I will make many mighty wonders and signs to become manifest at thy shrine.

Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲛ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲉⲧⲛⲁⲉⲓ ⲉⲡⲉⲕⲧⲟⲡⲟⲥ ⲛϥⲉⲣⲏⲧ ⲛϥⲧⲙⲧⲁⲁⲩ · ϯⲛⲁϫⲓϩⲁⲡ ⲛⲙⲙⲁϥ ϩⲁⲣⲟⲟⲩ :—
Translation: Whosoever shall come to thy shrine, and shall make a vow, and shall not pay the same, because of these unpaid vows will I enter into judgement with them.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲡⲉⲓⲡⲩⲣⲅⲟⲥ ⲉⲧⲕⲟⲩⲏⲏϩ ⲛϩⲏⲧϥ · ⲥⲉⲛⲁⲱϫⲛ ⲁⲛ ⲛϭⲓⲙⲙⲏⲏϣⲉ ⲉⲧⲛⲏⲩ ⲉⲣⲁⲧⲕ ⲛⲉⲕⲡⲟⲗⲓⲧⲉⲓⲁ ⲙⲛⲛⲉⲕⲙⲛⲧϫⲱⲱⲣⲉ ⲛⲁⲃⲱⲕ ϣⲁⲁⲣⲏϫϥ ⲙⲡⲕⲁϩ ·
Translation: As for this tower wherein thou dwellest, the multitudes who shall come thereto shall not destroy it, (The story of) thy life and conversation and of thy great valour shall reach the uttermost ends of the earth.

Verse: ⲕⲛⲁⲣ ⲧⲉⲓⲣⲟⲙⲡⲉ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲝⲱⲣⲓⲥⲧⲓⲁ · ϩⲣⲁⲓ ϩⲛⲧⲕⲉⲣⲟⲙⲡⲉ ⲥⲉⲛⲁϥⲓ ⲛⲧⲉⲕⲁⲡⲉ ϩⲛⲧⲙⲏⲏⲧⲉ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲕⲁⲥⲧⲣⲟⲛ ϩⲛⲧⲥⲏϥⲉ ·
Translation: This year shalt thou dwell in exile, but in the next year they shall cut off thy head with the sword in this Camp

Verse: ⲕⲛⲁϣⲉⲡ ϩⲉⲛⲕⲉⲕⲟⲩⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲛϩⲓⲥⲉ ⲉϫⲙⲡⲁⲣⲁⲛ ·
Translation: for thou shalt suffer certain pains for My Names sake.

Verse: ϯⲛⲏⲩ ⲟⲛ ⲛⲧⲁϯϭⲟⲙ ⲛⲁⲕ ϣⲁⲛⲧⲕϯϣⲓⲡⲉ ⲙⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ ⲙⲛⲛⲉϥⲃⲁⲥⲁⲛⲟⲥ ·
Translation: And I will come unto thee again, and I will give thee strength until thou shalt have put to shame the Duke and his torturings.

Verse: ⲛⲧⲉⲩⲛⲟⲩ ⲁⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲡⲁϩⲧϥ ⲙⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲉϥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ·
Translation: And straightway Apa Victor cast himself down at the feet of the Lord, saying

Verse: ϫⲉⲁⲛⲅ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ϫⲉⲁⲓⲣ ⲙⲡϣⲁ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲕϣⲁϫⲉ ⲛⲙⲙⲁⲓ ⲱ ⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ·
Translation: Who am I, that I should be deemed worthy by Thee for Thee to speak to, O my Lord?

Verse: ⲁⲓⲥ ⲁⲥⲡⲁⲍⲉ ⲙⲙⲟϥ · ⲁϥⲃⲱⲕ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲉⲙⲡⲏⲩⲉ · ⲉⲩϩⲩⲙⲛⲉⲩⲉ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ⲛϭⲓⲛⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ·
Translation: And Jesus kissed him, and He departed into heaven, and the angels sang hymns to Him.

Verse: ⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲉϥϣⲟⲟⲡ ϩⲙⲡⲕⲁⲥⲧⲣⲟⲛ :— ⲉⲣⲉⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ϣⲟⲟⲡ ⲛⲙⲙⲁϥ ·
Translation: And Apa Victor continued to live in the Camp, and the Lord Jesus was with him.

Verse: ⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥϣⲱⲡ ⲛⲁϥ ⲛⲧⲉϥⲕⲁⲓⲥⲉ ⲙⲛⲧⲉϥⲧⲁⲓⲃⲉ ·
Translation: And Apa Victor purchased for himself the materials for his burial, and his coffin.

Verse: ⲡⲕⲁⲥⲧⲣⲟⲛ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥⲁϣⲁⲓ ⲙⲙⲁⲧⲟⲓ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ · ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲙⲁⲕⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ·
Translation: And large numbers of soldiers flocked to the Camp for the sake of the blessed man Apa Victor.

Verse: ⲡⲙⲁⲕⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲁϥⲃⲱⲕ ⲛⲛⲉϥϣⲗⲏⲗ ⲉⲧϥⲉⲓⲣⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛⲉϥⲉⲓⲣⲉ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲛⲏⲥⲧⲉⲓⲁ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛⲉϥϩⲁⲣⲉϩ ⲉⲛⲉϥⲥⲁⲃⲃⲁⲧⲟⲛ · ⲉⲣⲉⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ϣⲟⲟⲡ ⲛⲙⲙⲁϥ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲉⲓⲣⲏⲛⲏ ⲛⲧⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ · ⲉⲣⲉⲛⲉϥⲥⲙⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲟⲩⲁⲁⲃ ⲛⲁϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲛⲙⲙⲁⲛ ϩⲁⲙⲏⲛ :
Translation: And the blessed man Apa Victor doubled the number of the prayers which he used to make, and he ke2)t fasts for very long periods, and he diligently observed the Sabbaths, and the Lord Jesus was with him. In the peace of God, May His holy blessing be with us! Amen

Verse: ⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ ⲇⲉ ⲥⲉⲃⲁⲥⲧⲓⲁⲛⲟⲥ ⲁϥⲉⲓ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲉⲙⲉϣⲧⲡⲕⲁⲥⲧⲣⲟⲛ ·
Translation: And Sebastianus, the Duke, came to inspect the Camp.

Verse: ⲁⲥⲧⲉⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲡⲉⲡⲣⲁⲓⲧⲱⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲙⲡⲕⲁⲥⲧⲣⲟⲛ · ⲁϥⲡⲁϩⲧϥ ϩⲓⲧϩⲏ ⲙⲡⲕⲟⲙⲉⲥ · ⲉⲣⲉⲥⲟⲧⲏⲣⲓⲭⲟⲥ ⲟ ⲛⲟⲩⲙⲉⲗⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ · ⲁϥϯ ⲛⲁϥ ⲙⲡⲗⲓⲃⲉⲗⲗⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ · ⲉⲧⲣⲉϥⲡⲁⲣϩⲓⲥⲧⲁ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ⲛⲁϥ ·
Translation: And Asterius, the praetor of the Camp, cast himself down before the Count, and Soterichos, who was the accountant (or, clerk), gave him a written statement concerning Apa Victor, so that he might summon him into his presence.

Verse: ⲧⲟⲧⲉ ⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ ⲁϥⲕⲉⲗⲉⲩⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲩⲡⲱⲣϣ ⲙⲡⲃⲏⲙⲁ ⲙⲡϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲛⲧⲡⲩⲗⲏ ⲙⲡⲕⲁⲥⲧⲣⲟⲛ · ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉϥⲉⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲉⲡⲡⲉⲧⲟⲩⲁⲁⲃ ⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ·
Translation: Then the Duke ordered his servants to set his judgement throne inside the gate of the Camp, in order that he might hear (the case of) the holy man Apa Victor.

Verse: ϩⲧⲟⲟⲩⲉ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲉϥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲁϥϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ ⲉⲡⲃⲏⲙⲁ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ · ⲁϥⲟⲩⲉϩⲥⲁϩⲛⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲩⲡⲁⲣϩⲓⲥⲧⲁ ⲛⲁϥ ⲙⲡⲇⲓⲕⲁⲓⲟⲥ ·
Translation: And when the morning had come the Duke took his seat upon the throne, and he commanded his servants to bring the righteous man into his presence.

Verse: ⲛⲕⲉⲥⲧⲱⲛⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲇⲉ ⲁⲩϭⲱⲡⲉ ⲛⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲛϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲛⲧⲉϥⲣⲓ · ⲉⲣⲉϩⲉⲛⲑⲁⲣⲙⲟⲩⲥ ϩⲛⲧⲉϥϭⲓϫ ⲉϥⲟⲩⲱⲙ ·
Translation: And the torturers seized Apa Victor whilst he was in his cell, and he had lentils in his hand, and he was eating

Verse: ⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲇⲉ ⲁϥⲛⲉϫ ⲛⲧϩⲁⲣⲙⲟⲩⲥ ⲉⲡⲉⲥⲏⲧ ⲉⲡϣⲟⲩϣⲧ ⲉϥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ·
Translation: and Apa Victor threw the lentils through the window, saying

Verse: ϫⲉⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ⲉⲕⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛⲉⲓⲑⲁⲣⲙⲟⲥ ⲣⲱⲛⲉ ⲛⲥⲉⲧⲙⲱϫⲛ ϣⲁⲉⲛⲉϩ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛⲥⲉϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲙⲙⲁⲉⲓⲛ ⲛⲛⲅⲉⲛⲉⲁ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲛⲏⲩ · ⲙⲏⲡⲟⲧⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲛⲉⲓⲁⲥⲉⲃⲏⲥ ϩⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲟⲩ ·
Translation: O my Lord Jesus the Christ, do Thou make these lentils to become stones which shall never be destroyed! And they shall be a sign unto all the generations which are to come, lest these wicked men tread them down.'

Verse: ⲁϥϣⲗⲏⲗ ⲇⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ⲉϥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ·
Translation: And Apa Victor prayed, saying,

Verse: ϫⲉⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲓⲏⲥⲟⲩⲥ ⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ⲙⲡⲣϯϣⲓⲡⲉ ⲛⲁⲓ ϩⲓⲧϩⲏ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲁⲛⲟⲙⲟⲥ ·
Translation: O my Lord Jesus the Christ, let me not be put to shame before this wicked man.'

Verse: ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲱⲥ ⲁϥⲉⲓ ⲉⲡⲉⲥⲏⲧ ⲙⲛⲙⲙⲁⲧⲟⲓ · ⲁϥⲁϩⲉⲣⲁⲧϥ ϩⲓⲧϩⲏ ⲙⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ ·
Translation: And afterwards he came down (from his cell), and stood before the Duke.

Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ ⲛⲁϥ
Translation: And the Duke said unto him,

Verse: ϫⲉϩⲉⲛⲥϩⲁⲓ ⲛⲉ ⲛⲁⲓ · ⲛⲧⲁⲡⲣⲣⲟ
Translation: These are the letters which the Emperor hath sent to be read unto thee; hearken unto them, and offer up sacrifice.'

Verse: ⲁⲗⲏⲑⲱⲥ ϯⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ ⲙⲙⲟⲓ ⲉⲓϫⲓ ⲛⲥⲉ ⲛⲁⲛⲛⲱⲛⲛⲁ · ⲉⲣⲉⲡⲁⲉⲓⲱⲧ ⲟ ⲛⲥⲧⲣⲁⲧⲏⲗⲁⲧⲏⲥ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲉⲣⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲙⲟⲥⲧⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲓ ϫⲉⲉⲓϫⲓ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ϩⲛⲟⲩϫⲓ ⲛϭⲟⲛⲥ ·
Translation: Verily, I know well that I did receive a salary of sixty from my father, who is a general, and that God hated me because I received these things wickedly.

Verse: ⲧⲉⲛⲟⲩ ϭⲉ ⲱ ⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ · ⲙⲛⲛⲟⲩⲃ ⲟⲩⲇⲉ ⲙⲛϩⲁⲧ ⲛⲁϣ ⲛⲉ ϩⲙⲡⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲙⲡⲛⲁⲩ ⲛⲧⲉϥⲁⲛⲁⲅⲕⲏ ·
Translation: Now therefore, O Duke, neither gold nor silver will be of the least value to a man in the hour of his necessity.

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲓ ϭⲉ ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲙⲓϣⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ · ϫⲉⲟⲩⲟⲃϣⲥ ⲧⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲩⲕⲁⲁⲥ ϩⲓϫⲙⲡⲉⲛϩⲏⲧ · ⲉⲧⲙⲣⲡⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ⲙⲡⲙⲟⲩ ⲙⲡⲓⲁⲓⲱⲛ ·
Translation: For this reason let us fight with ourselves, for forgetfulness hath spread itself over our heart, so that we may never cease to remember the death (which cometh) in this world.

Verse: ⲙⲙⲟⲛ ⲁⲓϫⲓ ⲉϩⲟⲟⲩ ϩⲱ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁⲓϫⲓⲥⲉ ·
Translation: I have never glorified myself, and I have never exalted myself.

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲓ ⲁⲡⲉⲧⲥⲏϩ ϫⲱⲕ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲉϫⲱⲓ · ϫⲉⲡⲉⲧϫⲓⲥⲉ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ⲥⲉⲛⲁⲑⲃⲃⲓⲟϥ · ⲡⲉⲧⲑⲃⲃⲓⲟ ⲇⲉ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ⲥⲉⲛⲁϫⲁⲥⲧϥ ·
Translation: For this reason that which is written is fulfilled in me: 'He who exalteth himself shall be abased, and he who abaseth himself shall be exalted.'

Verse: ⲧⲟⲧⲉ ⲥⲉⲃⲁⲥⲧⲓⲁⲛⲟⲥ ⲁϥϭⲱⲛⲧ ⲉⲙⲁⲧⲉ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁϥ ϫⲉⲑⲩⲥⲓⲁⲍⲉ ·
Translation: Then Sebastianus was exceedingly wroth, and he said unto Apa Victor, 'Offer up sacrifice.'

Verse: ⲁϥⲟⲩⲱϣⲃ ϫⲉⲛϯⲛⲁⲑⲩⲥⲓⲁⲍⲉ ⲁⲛ ·
Translation: And Apa Victor answered and said, 'I will not offer up sacrifice.

Verse: ⲡⲉⲧⲉϩⲛⲁⲕ ⲧⲏⲣϥ ⲁⲣⲓϥ ⲛⲁⲓ ·
Translation: Whatsoever thou wishest to do unto me that do.

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲁⲓϩⲉ ⲉⲧⲟⲟⲧⲟⲩ ⲛϥⲧⲟⲟⲩ ⲛⲇⲓⲕⲁⲥⲧⲏⲣⲓⲟⲛ ϣⲁⲧⲉⲛⲟⲩ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲙⲡⲓⲣϩⲟⲧⲉ ϩⲏⲧⲟⲩ · ϫⲉⲁⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ϯϭⲟⲙ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲛϩⲏⲧⲟⲩ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ·
Translation: I fell into the hands of the four torturers (?) before this, and I was not afraid of them, for the Lord gave me strength during all my torturings.

Verse: ⲧⲉⲛⲟⲩ ϭⲉ ⲱ ⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ · ⲛⲧⲁⲩⲉⲝⲱⲣⲓⲍⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲓ ⲉⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲉⲓⲣⲁⲛ ϫⲉⲑⲩⲥⲓⲁⲍⲉ ·
Translation: Now therefore, O Duke, I was banished to this spot because of this Name, for (they said), 'Offer up sacrifice,'

Verse: ϯⲟⲩⲱϣ ϭⲉ ⲁⲛ ⲉⲧⲣⲁϭⲱ ϩⲙⲡⲉⲓⲕⲟⲥⲙⲟⲥ ⲉⲧⲛⲁⲃⲱⲗ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲛϥⲧⲁⲕⲟ ·
Translation: (and I would not do so). And, moreover, I do not wish to remain in this world which shall dissolve away and perish.

Verse: ⲉⲓⲙⲉ ϭⲉ ⲛⲁⲕ ⲱ ⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ · ϫⲉⲉⲕϣⲁⲛⲃⲁⲥⲁⲛⲓⲍⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲓ ⲛⲟⲩⲙⲏⲏϣⲉ ⲛⲥⲟⲡ · ⲉⲕϯⲛⲟⲩⲙⲛⲧϫⲁⲣϩⲏⲧ ⲛϩⲟⲩⲟ ⲙⲡⲁⲗⲟⲅⲓⲥⲙⲟⲥ ⲉⲧϩⲙⲡⲁⲥⲁ ⲛϩⲟⲩⲛ ·
Translation: Be it known unto thee also, O Duke, that if thou put me to the torture many, many times, thou wilt only give additional strength to the reasoning power of the mind which is within me.

Verse: ϩⲟϯ ⲙⲉⲛ ϫⲉⲁⲓⲣⲙⲡϣⲁ ϩⲱⲗⲱⲥ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲩⲥⲟϣⲧ ⲉϫⲙⲡⲣⲁⲛ ⲙⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ·
Translation: Wholly fitting for me is it that I should be held worthy to endure revilings for the Name of the Christ.'

Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲉⲡⲇⲟⲩⲝ ⲛⲁⲡⲁ ⲃⲓⲕⲧⲱⲣ ·
Translation: And the Duke said unto Apa Victor,

Verse: ϫⲉⲁⲗⲟⲕ ⲉⲕⲟ ⲛϩⲁϩ ⲛϣⲁϫⲉ ·
Translation: Cease thy say; thou art always talking!

Verse: ⲙⲏ
Translation: Art thou a deacon, or a reader, that thou possessest such perfect knowledge of this (kind) of wisdom?

Verse: ⲡⲙⲁⲕⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲡⲁⲩⲗⲟⲥ ⲡⲁⲡⲟⲥⲧⲟⲗⲟⲥ ⲛⲛϩⲉⲑⲛⲟⲥ ⲡⲉⲛⲧⲁϥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲛⲥⲁϩ ⲛⲧⲉⲕⲕⲗⲏⲥⲓⲁ ⲡⲉⲛⲧⲁϥⲁⲅⲱⲛⲓⲍⲉ ⲉⲧⲛⲧⲱⲛϥ ⲉⲛⲇⲩⲛⲁⲙⲓⲥ ⲛⲁⲥⲱⲙⲁⲧⲟⲥ ϩⲛⲧⲉϥⲡⲟⲗⲩⲧⲧⲓⲁ
Translation: If the blessed man Paul, the Apostle of the Gentiles,

Verse: ⲡⲉⲓⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ⲉⲧⲏⲡ ⲉⲡⲕⲁϩ ·
Translation: this angel who belonged to the earth,

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲡⲉⲓⲣⲱⲙⲉ
Translation: this man who belonged to the heavens,

Verse: ⲡⲉⲧⲉⲙⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲙⲡⲁⲣϩⲓⲥⲧⲁ ⲙⲡⲉϥⲙⲉ ⲙⲛⲡⲉϥⲕⲱϩ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ·
Translation: who was by reason of his love and zeal well nigh the equal of Christ,

Verse: ⲡϥⲁⲓⲣⲟⲟⲩϣ ⲛⲛⲉⲕⲕⲗⲏⲥⲓⲁ ·
Translation: who bore the care of the Churches,

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲁⲡⲉⲓⲣⲱⲙⲉ ϭⲉ ⲉⲧⲟⲩⲁⲁⲃ ⲉⲧⲉⲩⲛⲧⲁϥ ⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲏⲏϣⲉ ⲛⲁⲣⲉⲧⲏ ⲡⲉ ⲛⲧⲁϥϫⲟⲟⲥ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲡⲁⲣⲣⲏⲥⲓⲁ ϫⲉϯⲥⲟⲟⲩⲛ ⲁⲛ ⲛⲗⲁⲁⲩ ⲁⲛⲟⲕ ⲉⲁⲓⲁⲁϥ ·
Translation: and, moreover, if this holy man, who possessed in his own person so great a multitude of spiritual excellences, and who spake out boldly, saying, 'I know not how to do anything of myself,'

Verse: ⲁϥⲣϩⲟⲧⲉ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲁϥϣⲁϫⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲓϩⲉ ·
Translation: was afraid, and spake in a manner,

Verse: ⲉⲓⲉ ⲟⲩ ⲡⲉⲧⲛⲛⲁⲁⲁϥ ⲁⲛⲟⲛ ⲛⲉⲓⲧⲁⲗⲁⲓⲡⲱⲣⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲉⲙⲡⲟⲩⲕⲁⲧⲟⲣⲑⲟⲩ ⲛⲗⲁⲁⲩ ⲛⲁⲣⲉⲧⲏ ·
Translation: what shall we ourselves do, who are miserable creatures, and who are wholly unable to cultivate successfully one spiritual excellence?

Verse: ⲟⲩⲕ ⲟⲩⲛⲡⲉⲧⲉϣϣⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ⲡⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛⲣⲟⲉⲓⲥ
Translation: It is not then seemly for us to keep watch and to pray at all times, 'and to make petitions to God neither for gold not silver, nor for any riches of this world, but only for riches which are in the heavens;

Verse: ϣⲁⲣⲉϩⲟⲓⲛⲉ ⲙⲉⲛ ⲉⲩⲫⲣⲁⲛⲉ ⲉϫⲛⲟⲩⲙⲛⲧⲣⲙⲙⲁⲟ ·
Translation: Now, there are certain folk who rejoice in [their] wealth;

Verse: ϩⲉⲛⲕⲟⲟⲩⲉ ⲇⲉ ⲉϫⲛϩⲉⲛⲙⲁ ⲛⲥⲱ ⲙⲛϩⲉⲛϭⲓⲛⲟⲩⲟⲟⲙ ·
Translation: and some rejoice in wine-drinkings in taverns, and in eating at feasts,

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲓ ⲡⲉⲧⲉϣϣⲉ ⲡⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛϥⲓⲡⲣⲟⲟⲩϣ ϩⲁⲧⲉⲛⲯⲩⲭⲏ ·
Translation: For this reason it is seemly for us to take strict care of our souls at all times,

Verse: ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓϣ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛϫⲟⲟⲥ
Translation: and we must say as did the Holy man David, 'God giveth strength to my beauty,'

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲕⲁⲛ ⲉⲣϣⲁⲛⲕⲁⲧⲟⲣⲑⲟⲩ ⲛⲧⲁⲣⲉⲧⲏ ϯϩⲧⲏ ⲉⲧⲙϫⲓⲥⲉ ⲛϩⲏⲧ ⲉϫⲙⲡⲟⲩⲥⲁ ·
Translation: But even if it be thy spiritual excellence flourisheth, take good heed that thy heart but not over-exalted because of thy beauty,

Verse: ⲙⲏⲡⲟⲧⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ
Translation: lest God turn His face away from thee because of thine exaltation of heart (or, pride).

Verse: ⲡⲉⲧϯϩⲣⲉ ⲛⲥⲁⲣⲝ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲁϥⲛⲏⲥⲧⲉⲩⲉ ϩⲛⲧⲥⲁⲣⲝ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧⲉ ·
Translation: He Who gave food unto all flesh fasted in the flesh for thy sake

Verse: ⲡⲉⲛⲧⲁϥⲧⲁⲙⲓⲟ ⲉⲡⲉϩⲗⲟϭ ⲙⲡⲉⲃⲓⲱ ·
Translation: He Who created the sweetness in the honey

Verse: ⲁϥϫⲓϯⲡⲉ ⲛⲟⲩⲥⲓϣⲉ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧⲉ ·
Translation: tasted that which was bitter (gall) for thy sake.

Verse: ⲡⲉⲧⲕⲟⲥⲙⲉⲓ ⲛⲧⲡⲉ
Translation: He Who ornamented the heavens with the companies of the stars

Verse: ⲁϥⲫⲟⲣⲉⲓ ⲛⲟⲩⲕⲗⲟⲙ
Translation: wore a crown of thorns for thy sake;

Verse: ⲉⲁϥϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲛⲥⲧⲙⲏⲧ ϣⲁⲁ
Translation: and He became obedient even unto death,

Verse: ⲟⲩⲙⲟⲩ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲥⲧⲁⲩⲣⲟⲥ ·
Translation: the death of the Cross.

Verse: ⲟⲩⲕ ⲟⲩⲛⲡⲉⲧⲉϣϣⲉ ⲁⲛ ⲡⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛϣⲟⲩϣⲟⲩ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ ϩⲛⲛⲁⲓ ·
Translation: It is not, then, seemly for us to shew ourselves glad because of these things,

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛⲧⲟⲉⲓⲧ ⲛⲧⲛⲣⲓⲙⲉ ⲛⲧⲛⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲥⲁⲡⲉⲧϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲙⲕⲁϩ ⲛϩⲏⲧ ⲉϫⲛⲛⲉⲧⲧⲉⲧⲛϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ϩⲛⲛⲉⲧⲛϩⲏⲧ ϩⲓϫⲛⲛⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁ ⲛⲛⲕⲟⲧⲕ ·
Translation: nay, we must make ourselves to lament, and we must weep. Let us hearken unto that which [the Book] saith, '[Be] sorrowful in heart upon your beds

Verse: ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲛⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲛⲁⲁⲩ ϩⲙⲡⲉϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲉⲛⲁⲣⲡⲉⲩⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲟⲩϣⲏ · ⲛⲧⲛⲁϣⲁϩⲟⲙ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲉϫⲱⲟⲩ ·
Translation: because of the things which ye have said in your hearts [during the day],' so that we may have in remembrance in the night season, and that we may heave sighs concerning them.

Verse: ⲧⲁⲓ ⲧⲉ ⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲧⲁϥⲁⲁⲥ ⲛϭⲓⲁⲭⲁⲃ ⲛⲧⲉⲣⲉϥⲙⲕⲁϩ ⲛϩⲏⲧ ·
Translation: This is what Ahab did when he was in sorrow:

Verse: ⲁϥⲛⲏⲥⲧⲉⲩⲉ ⲁϥⲙⲟⲣϥ ⲛⲟⲩϭⲟⲟⲩⲛⲉ ·
Translation: he fasted and he girded sackcloth about his body.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲟⲩ ⲡⲉ ⲛⲧⲁⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ϫⲟⲟϥ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧϥ ⲛⲛⲁⲉⲓⲛⲉ ⲛⲧⲕⲁⲕⲓⲁ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲉϫⲱϥ ϩⲛⲛⲉϥϩⲟⲟⲩ ·
Translation: And what did God say concerning him? 'I will not bring the evil upon him in his days.'

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲓ ⲣⲱ ⲁⲡⲥⲱⲧⲏⲣ ⲙⲁⲅⲁⲣⲓⲍⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲧⲣⲓⲙⲉ ·
Translation: It was for this same reason that the Saviour proclaimed to be blessed who weep,

Verse: ⲛⲉⲧⲣⲓⲙⲉ ⲁⲛ ⲉϫⲛⲟⲩⲕⲱⲱⲛⲥ ⲏ ⲡⲟⲥⲉ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲭⲣⲏⲙⲁ ·
Translation: not those who weep for the dead, or the loss of property,

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲉϫⲛⲛⲉⲩⲛⲟⲃⲉ ·
Translation: but those who weep for their sins.

Verse: ⲁϫⲓⲥ ϩⲱⲱⲕ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲇⲁⲩⲉⲓⲇ ϫⲉϯⲛⲁϫⲱⲕⲙ ⲙⲡⲁϭⲗⲟϭ ⲕⲁⲧⲁⲟⲩϣⲏ ⲟⲩϣⲏ ·
Translation: Though thyself shalt say even as did David, 'Night after night I wash my bed,

Verse: ϯⲛⲁϩⲱⲣⲡ ⲙⲡⲁⲡⲣⲏϣ ϩⲛⲛⲁⲣⲙⲉⲓⲟⲟⲩⲉ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲟⲛ ϫⲉⲁⲛⲁⲃⲁⲗ ⲧⲁⲩⲟ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲟⲑⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϫⲉⲙⲡⲟⲩϩⲁⲣⲉϩ ⲉⲡⲉⲕⲛⲟⲙⲟⲥ · ⲉⲓⲱ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲙⲡⲧⲱⲗⲙ ϩⲓⲧⲛ ⲛⲣⲙⲉⲓⲟⲟⲩⲉ ·
Translation: and I soak my cushion[s] with my tears.' 'Wash though away the defilement by means of tears,

Verse: ϩⲓⲟⲩⲉ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲕⲙⲉⲥⲧϩⲏⲧ ·
Translation: smite upon thy breast,

Verse: ϫⲓ ⲛⲁⲕ ⲙⲡⲣⲡⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲕⲛⲟⲃⲉ ·
Translation: and take to thyself the remembrance of the sins

Verse: ⲉⲛⲧⲁⲕⲁⲁⲩ ·
Translation: which though hast committed.

Verse: ⲁⲩϭⲱⲣϭ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓϣ ϩⲓⲧⲛⲛⲉⲕⲃⲁⲗ ·
Translation: [If] though hast been snared at [any] time through thine eye,

Verse: ⲁⲕⲟⲩⲱⲛ ⲛⲛⲉⲕϣⲟⲩϣⲧ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓϣ ⲕⲁⲕⲱⲥ ·
Translation: if though hast opened thy window at [any] time wickedly,

Verse: ⲁⲕⲡⲗⲁⲡⲧⲉⲓ ⲛⲧⲉⲕⲯⲩⲭⲏ ϩⲛⲛⲉⲕⲃⲁⲗ ·
Translation: thou hast done injury to thy soul through thine eye.

Verse: ⲛⲃⲁⲗ
Translation: The eyes which look with wicked intent

Verse: ⲑⲉⲣⲁⲡⲉⲩⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ⲧⲉⲛⲟⲩ ϩⲓⲧⲛⲛⲣⲙⲉⲓⲟⲟⲩⲉ
Translation: heal thou now with tears,

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ϣⲧⲁⲙ ⲛⲛⲉⲕϣⲟⲩϣⲧ ⲉⲧⲙⲑⲉⲱⲣⲉⲓ
Translation: and shut thou thy window that thou mayest not see again the things of vanity,

Verse: ϫⲉⲛⲉⲕϩⲉ
Translation: for otherwise, thou wilt fall into an evil habit.

Verse: ϣⲁⲣⲉⲧⲥⲩⲛⲏⲑⲓⲁ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲥⲉⲕⲡⲉⲧⲛⲁⲟⲩⲁϩϥ ⲛⲥⲱⲥ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲉϩⲉⲛⲛⲟϭ ⲛⲛⲟⲃⲉ ·
Translation: Now habit is wont to draw him that clingeth thereto into great sins.

Verse: ⲁⲕⲫⲟⲣⲉⲓ ⲛⲟⲩϩⲃⲥⲱ ⲉⲥⲡⲣⲉⲓⲱⲟⲩ ϯϩⲧⲏⲕ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ⲉⲧⲙϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ϩⲙⲙⲁ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲙⲏⲡⲟⲧⲉ ⲛⲥⲧⲱⲗⲙ ·
Translation: [When] though hast arrived thyself splendid apparel 'take good heed unto thyself not to sit down in any [dirty] place, 'lest it become spotted.

Verse: ⲉⲕϣⲁⲛⲕⲁⲧⲁⲫⲣⲟⲛⲉⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲙⲡϣⲟⲣⲡ ⲛⲧⲱⲗⲙ ⲙⲛⲡⲙⲉϩⲥⲛⲁⲩ ⲙⲛⲡⲙⲉϩϣⲟⲙⲛⲧ ⲗⲟⲓⲡⲟⲛ ϩⲱⲥ ⲉⲁⲧϩⲟⲓⲧⲉ ⲧⲱⲗⲙ ⲧⲏⲣⲥ ·
Translation: If thou shalt hold to be in a light matter the first stain, and the second, and the third, at length thy whole garment shall become dirty.

Verse: ⲙⲉⲕϫⲛⲁⲁⲩ ⲉϩⲙⲟⲟⲥ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ϩⲙⲙⲁ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲉϥϫⲁϩⲙ ·
Translation: 'Thou shalt not be careless [and] sit down in any polluted place whatsoever.

Verse: ⲟⲩ ϭⲉ ⲡⲉⲧⲛⲛⲁⲁϥ ⲧⲉⲭⲣⲉⲓⲁ ⲧⲉⲛⲟⲩ ϣⲗⲏⲗ ⲉϥϭⲙϭⲟⲙ ·
Translation: What are we to do then? [Thou hast] need to fervent prayer,

Verse: ⲙⲏⲡⲟⲧⲉ ⲛⲅϫⲱⲣⲡ ⲉⲩⲱⲛⲉ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲕⲟⲩⲉⲣⲏⲧⲉ ·
Translation: lest thou strike a stone with thy feet.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲣⲉⲡⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ⲙⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲕⲱⲧⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ⲛϥⲛⲁϩⲙⲉⲕ · ⲛⲅϭⲙϭⲟⲙ ϩⲱⲱⲕ ⲉϫⲟⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲡⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ⲉⲧⲛⲟⲩϩⲙ ⲙⲙⲟⲓ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲙⲡⲉⲧϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲛⲓⲙ ·
Translation: And [thou shalt pray fervently] that the Angel shall compass three round about, and shall deliver thee. And thou thyself shalt be strong and shalt say, 'The Angel who delivered me out of evil,'

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ϩⲱⲱⲕ ⲉⲣⲉⲡⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ⲙⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲕ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲛⲧⲡⲉ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲁⲃⲣⲁϩⲁⲙ ·
Translation: 'And [thou shalt pray fervently] that the Angel may cry out unto thee from heaven, even as [he cried] to Abraham,

Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲛⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ⲥⲉⲙⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲧⲙⲉ ⲙⲡⲉⲩϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲙⲙⲓⲛⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ·
Translation: for the Angels love those who love their own God.

Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ϫⲉϫⲓ ⲛⲟⲩⲯⲁⲗⲙⲟⲥ ⲛⲧⲉⲧⲛϯ ⲛⲟⲩⲧⲩⲙⲡⲁⲛⲟⲛ ·
Translation: He (i.e., the Book) saith moreover, 'Take a psalm, set ye forth a tabret,

Verse: ⲟⲩⲯⲁⲗⲧⲏⲣⲓⲟⲛ ⲉϥⲛⲟⲧⲙ ⲙⲛⲟⲩⲕⲓⲑⲁⲣⲁ ·
Translation: a sweet psaltry and a harp';

Verse: ⲟⲩⲁ ⲡⲉ ϣⲁⲕϫⲓⲧϥ ⲥⲉⲁⲡⲉⲧⲉⲓ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ⲛϣⲟⲙⲛⲧ ·
Translation: thou art to take one thing, and three are demanded from thee.

Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲉⲛⲥⲩⲛϩⲓⲥⲧⲁ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲛϣⲟⲙⲛⲧ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲉⲧⲉⲣⲉⲡⲁⲡⲟⲥⲧⲟⲗⲟⲥ ϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲉϥⲉϩⲁⲣⲉϩ ⲉⲡⲉⲧⲙⲡⲛⲉⲩⲙⲁ ⲉϥⲟⲩⲟϫ ⲙⲛⲧⲉⲧⲛⲯⲩⲭⲏ ⲙⲛⲡⲉⲧⲛⲥⲱⲙⲁ ·
Translation: For we are composed of three things, even as the Apostle [Paul] spake, 'He will keep safe him that is in the spirit, and He will make healthy your souls and your bodies.'

Verse: ⲡⲉⲯⲁⲗⲧⲏⲣⲓⲟⲛ ⲙⲉⲛ ⲡⲉ ⲡⲉⲡⲛⲉⲩⲙⲁ ·
Translation: Now the psaltery is in the spirit,

Verse: ⲧⲕⲓⲑⲁⲣⲁ ⲇⲉ ⲧⲉ ⲧⲉⲯⲩⲭⲏ ·
Translation: the harp is in the soul,

Verse: ⲡⲧⲩⲡⲡⲁⲛⲟⲛ ⲇⲉ ⲟⲩϣⲁⲁⲣ ⲉϥⲙⲟⲟⲩⲧ ⲡⲉⲧϩⲓⲱⲱϥ ·
Translation: and the tabret is the dead skin which covereth it.

Verse: ⲙⲟⲩⲟⲩⲧ ϭⲉ ⲛⲧⲥⲁⲣⲝ ·
Translation: Therefore, put thou to death the flesh,

Verse: ⲧⲁⲣⲉⲕⲉϣϭⲙϭⲟⲙ ⲉⲥⲙⲟⲩ
Translation: and this shalt thou make thyself strong to ascribe blessings to God with the tabret and dance.

Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲛⲧⲟϥ ⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲁϥⲙⲟⲩϩ ⲛⲧⲥⲁⲣⲝ ϩⲁⲣⲟⲕ ·
Translation: For it is God Himself Who hath filled thee with flesh.

Verse: ϭⲱϣⲧ ⲙⲏⲡⲱⲥ ⲛϥϫⲟⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲕ ϫⲉⲟⲩ ⲡⲉ ⲡϩⲏⲩ ⲙⲡⲁⲥⲛⲟϥ ·
Translation: Observe, therefore, lest He should say unto thee, 'What profit is there in My blood?'

Verse: ⲟⲩ ϭⲉ ⲡⲉⲧⲕⲛⲁϣⲧⲟⲩⲉⲓⲟϥ ⲙⲡⲉⲛⲧⲁϥϣⲉⲡⲛⲉⲓϩⲓⲥⲉ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ϩⲁⲣⲟⲕ ·
Translation: What kind of recompense canst thou possibly make to Him which shall be adequate for all the sufferings which He endured on thy behalf?

Verse: ϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲛⲟⲩϣⲏⲛ ⲛⲣⲉϥϯⲕⲁⲣⲡⲟⲥ ⲧⲁⲣⲉⲡⲉⲥⲙⲟⲩ ⲙⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ϣⲱⲡⲉ ϩⲓϫⲱⲕ ·
Translation: Be thou a tree which beareth fruit, and thus shall thou cause the blessing of God to be upon thee.

Verse: ϯⲕⲁⲣⲡⲟⲥ ⲕⲁⲧⲁⲧⲉⲕϭⲟⲙ ·
Translation: Bring forth fruit according to thy strength

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲙⲛϣϭⲟⲙ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ⲉϯϣⲉ ⲉⲧⲉⲡⲧⲉⲗⲓⲟⲛ
Translation: If thou art not able to bring forth an hundredfold, which is the [number of] perfection, then bring forth sixtyfold, which is the half thereof;

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲕⲛⲁϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲁⲛ ⲛⲟⲩⲥⲕⲉⲩⲟⲥ ⲛⲛⲟⲩⲃ ϩⲓϩⲁⲧ · ⲙⲡⲣϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲟⲛ ⲛϣⲉ ϩⲓⲭⲟⲣⲧⲟⲥ ϩⲓⲣⲟⲟⲩⲉ · ⲉⲧⲉⲛⲁⲓ ⲛⲉ ⲧϩⲩⲗⲏ ⲙⲡⲕⲱϩⲧ ·
Translation: If thou cast not be a vessel of gold, or silver, do not become a log of wood, or grass, or straw, which are merely fuel for the burning.

Verse: ⲙⲡⲣⲣⲛⲉϩⲃⲏⲩⲉ
Translation: Thou shall not perform the works which God hateth, for they shall take their stand before thee on the Day of Judgement like solid image(s).

Verse: ⲛⲅⲁⲣⲭⲉⲓ ⲗⲟⲓⲡⲟⲛ ⲉϩⲟⲙⲟⲗⲟⲅⲉⲓ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲭⲱⲣⲓⲥ ⲙⲛⲧⲣⲉ ·
Translation: And finally thou wilt have to begin to confess them in that place without witnesses

Verse: ⲭⲱⲣⲓⲥ ⲕⲁⲧⲏⲅⲟⲣⲟⲥ ⲭⲱⲣⲓⲥ ⲁⲡⲟⲇⲓⲝⲓⲥ ·
Translation: and without an advocate, and without proofs,

Verse: ϩⲙⲡⲧⲣⲉⲕⲑⲉⲱⲣⲉⲓ ⲛⲛⲉⲛⲧⲁⲕⲁⲁⲩ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ·
Translation: and thou wilt have to look upon the deeds

Verse: ⲙⲛⲛⲉⲛⲧⲁⲕϫⲟⲟⲩ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲙⲛⲧⲁⲧϯϩⲧⲏϥ
Translation: which thou hast uttered unwittingly, and they shall stand up like statues before thine eyes.

Verse: ϩⲟⲥⲟⲛ ⲟⲩⲛⲧⲁⲛ ⲡⲕⲁⲓⲣⲟⲥ ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲣϩⲱⲃ ·
Translation: So long then as we have the time let us do work,

Verse: ⲉⲣϣⲁⲛⲡⲕⲁⲓⲣⲟⲥ
Translation: for if the time slip through our hands,

Verse: ⲙⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛϩⲉ ⲉⲕⲉⲕⲉⲣⲟⲥ
Translation: 'it is unlikely that we shall find another opportunity.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲣⲓⲙⲉ ⲉϫⲛⲛⲉⲛϩⲃⲏⲩⲉ ⲉⲛⲧⲁⲛⲁⲁⲩ ⲕⲁⲕⲱⲥ ·
Translation: Let us then weep over the deeds which we have committted unrighteosly,

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲉⲛⲉⲛⲣⲙⲉⲓⲟⲟⲩⲉ ϣⲟⲩⲟ ⲉϫⲛⲛⲉⲛⲟⲩⲟϭⲉ · ⲙⲁⲣⲛϩⲓⲟⲩⲉ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ϩⲛⲛⲉⲛⲙⲉⲥⲧϩⲏⲧ ·
Translation: and let us make tears to flow down our cheeks in streams, and let us beat our breasts in sorrow,

Verse: ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ
Translation: 'so that we may do away with the weeping , and the gnashing of the teeth in that place whereto we mus depart.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲣⲓⲙⲉ ⲟⲛ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲇⲁⲩⲉⲓⲇ ·
Translation: 'Moreover, let us weep even as did David

Verse: ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲩⲛⲁⲙⲁⲅⲁⲣⲓⲍⲉ
Translation: in order that we may be proclaimed blessed. He did not shed a few tears only as men do when they weep,

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲁϥϫⲉⲕⲙⲡⲉϥϭⲗⲟϭ ϩⲛⲛⲉϥⲣⲙⲉⲓⲟⲟⲩⲉ
Translation: but he flooded his bed with his tears; and he passed the whole night in vigil.

Verse: ⲟⲩⲟⲩϣⲏ ⲛⲟⲩⲱⲧ
Translation: One night only he sinned,

Verse: ⲉⲡⲉⲓⲇⲏ ⲟⲩⲛ ⲁⲓⲡⲗⲁⲛⲏ ϩⲓⲧⲛⲛⲁⲃⲁⲗ ·
Translation: Since, therefore, I have gone astray through mine eyes,

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲓ
Translation: for this reason do away my sins through [my] tears.'

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲉⲓ
Translation: Let us come forth from our habits which are evil, , and remove ourselves into the city which is in the heavens.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲉⲧⲙⲉⲗⲉⲧⲁ ⲛⲛϣⲁϫⲉ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ϯϩⲣⲟⲕ ⲛⲛϩⲏⲇⲟⲛⲏ ⲉⲧⲟⲩⲏϩ ϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲛϩⲏⲧⲛ ·
Translation: 'Let the careful consideration of the words of God reduce to peace the delights of the senses which are engrained in our hearts,

Verse: ⲛⲁⲓ ⲉⲧⲟ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲑⲏⲣⲓⲟⲛ ⲛⲁⲅⲣⲓⲟⲛ ·
Translation: and which resemble those that are found in wild animals,

Verse: ϩⲙⲡⲧⲣⲉⲛϥⲓ
Translation: and let us bear at all times the death of our Lord Jesus Christ in our bodies,

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲉⲗⲁⲁⲩ ⲉϥⲛⲕⲟⲧⲕ ϫⲓⲕⲗⲟⲙ ·
Translation: The man that slumbereth shall not receive the crown of victory,

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲉⲗⲁⲁⲩ
Translation: and the man that is careless and idle shall not receive the prize,

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲡⲉⲧⲛⲁϥⲓϩⲁϩ ⲉⲛⲡⲗⲏⲅⲏ ⲙⲛϩⲉⲛⲥⲏϣⲉ ⲡⲁⲓ ⲡⲉⲧⲛⲁϫⲓⲧⲁⲓⲟ ϩⲓⲧⲙⲡⲁⲅⲱⲛⲱⲑⲉⲧⲏⲥ ·
Translation: but the man who hath borne innumerable buffetings and wounds is he who shall receive honour from the Master of the contest.

Verse: ϣⲁⲣⲉⲡϫⲁϫⲉ ⲙⲉⲛ ⲡⲱⲧ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲙⲡⲉⲧⲛⲏⲫⲉ ⲛϥⲥⲩⲗⲁ ϩⲱⲱϥ ⲙⲡⲉⲧⲛⲕⲟⲧⲕ :
Translation: Now the Enemy is in the habit of taking to flight before him that is prudent (or, cautious), but help undereth him that slumbereth.

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉ ⲡⲁⲓ ⲁⲕⲉⲓⲙⲉ ϫⲉⲟⲩⲛⲧⲁⲕ ϩⲉⲛϫⲁϫⲉ ⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲉⲩϩⲟⲟⲩ ·
Translation: Therefore, thou must know that thou hast about thee enemies which are evil.

Verse: ⲙⲡⲣϯϩⲓⲛⲏⲃ ⲛⲛⲉⲕⲃⲁⲗ ·
Translation: Give, therefore, no sleep to thine eyes,

Verse: ⲟⲩⲇⲉ ϩⲣⲉⲕⲣⲓⲕⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲕⲃⲟⲩϩⲉ ·
Translation: nor slumber to thine eyelids,

Verse: ϫⲉⲉⲕⲉⲣⲃⲟⲗ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲟⲩϣϭⲟⲥ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲛⲟⲩϩⲁϭⲉ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲟⲩϩⲁⲗⲏⲧ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲡⲁϣ ·
Translation: that thou mayest escape like a roe from the snare of the hunter, and like a bird from the net of the fowler.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲡⲱⲧ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓϣ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲛⲛⲣⲟⲟⲩϣ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲃⲓⲟⲥ ⲙⲛⲛⲉϥⲁⲗⲟⲩⲉ ·
Translation: Let us flee at all times from the cares of this world (or, life), and from the burdens thereof.

Verse: ⲉⲁⲛⲁⲡⲟⲧⲁⲥⲥⲉ ⲙⲡⲕⲟⲥⲙⲟⲥ
Translation: If we would make ourselves to be free from this world, we must not make to ourselves care for the things of the world,

Verse: ⲡⲱⲧ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲛⲙⲡⲁⲛⲟⲩⲣⲅⲓⲁ ⲙⲡⲉⲕⲣⲟϥ ·
Translation: 'Flee from the knavery of the Crafty One,

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ
Translation: and thou shalt say, ' Through Thee shall I be delivered from a company of thieves,

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ϩⲙⲡⲁⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ϯⲛⲁⲟⲩⲉⲧⲃⲟⲩⲥⲟⲃⲧ ·
Translation: and through my God I shall leap over a wall.'

Verse: ⲙⲡⲣⲡⲁⲣⲉⲧⲉⲓ
Translation: Seek not to excuse thyself from suffering, lest by so doing thou shalt excuse thyself from the crown also.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲉⲡⲉϣⲱⲧ ⲉⲛⲕⲁϭⲉⲓ ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ϣⲁϥϥⲓ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ϩⲁϩⲉⲛϩⲟⲉⲓⲙ ϫⲉⲉϥⲉϩⲉ ⲉⲛⲉⲭⲣⲏⲙⲁ ·
Translation: The merchant loseth not courage, but he endureth even the waves of the sea, and he findeth possessions.

Verse: ϣⲁⲣⲉⲡϣⲟⲉⲓϫ ⲉⲧⲁⲅⲱⲛⲓⲍⲉ ϥⲓ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ϩⲁⲛⲉⲡⲗⲩⲅⲏ · ⲉϥϭⲱϣⲧ ϩⲏⲧϥ ⲙⲡⲉⲕⲗⲟⲙ ·
Translation: He who contendeth is wont to fight in pain and suffering even unto wounds, for his heart looketh for the crown of victory.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲉⲡⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓ ϩⲉ ⲉⲕⲛⲁⲁⲩ ⲛⲥⲁⲃⲏⲗ ⲛϣⲟⲣⲡ ⲛϥϫⲟ ⲛⲛⲉϭⲣⲱⲱϭ ϩⲛⲛⲉϥϩⲓⲥⲉ ⲙⲙⲓⲛⲙⲙⲟϥ ·
Translation: The husbandman doth not find ears of corn [in his tillage] | unless he hath first of all sown the seed [thereof] by his own toil.

Verse: ⲧⲁⲓ ⲧⲉ ⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲧϭⲱϣⲧ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲏⲧⲥ ⲛⲧⲙⲛⲧⲣⲣⲟ ⲛⲙⲡⲏⲩⲉ ⲉϣⲁⲩⲉⲡⲛⲉⲑⲗⲓⲯⲓⲥ ϫⲉϩⲉⲛⲗⲁⲁⲩ ⲛⲉ ⲉⲩⲧⲏⲕ ⲛϩⲏⲧ ⲉϫⲛⲧϩⲉⲗⲡⲓⲥ ⲛⲛⲁⲅⲁⲑⲟⲛ ⲉⲧⲛⲁϣⲱⲡⲉ ·
Translation: This is what is to be expected from the kingdom which is in the heavens: : men must account tribulations as nothing whatsoever, and they must fortify their hearts by means of the hope of the good things which shall come.

Verse: ⲟⲩⲕ ⲟⲩⲛ ⲙⲁⲣⲛϯϩⲧⲏⲛ ⲛⲧⲛⲣⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓϣ ⲛⲓⲙ ϫⲉⲉⲣⲉⲡⲉⲛⲛⲩⲙⲫⲓⲟⲥ ⲛⲁϭⲱⲗⲧⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ
Translation: Let us therefore devote our whole attention to watching at all times, so that when our Bridegroom shall return, , and look in the bride-chamber,

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲡⲉⲧϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲡⲁϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲛⲁⲱⲥⲕⲥⲉⲛⲁⲡⲁϩϥ ϩⲓⲧⲉϥⲙⲏⲧⲉ ⲉⲓ ⲉⲡⲉⲧⲉⲛϥϭⲱϣⲧ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲏⲧϥ ⲁⲛ ⲉⲡⲧⲏⲣϥ ⲉⲩⲛⲁⲣⲟⲩ ⲛⲁϥ ·
Translation: If they shall cut asunder him that saith, ' My master tarrieth,' what shall they do unto him that doth not expect to see him at all?

Verse: ⲡⲉⲧⲉϣϣⲉ ⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ⲡⲉ ⲱ ⲛⲁⲙⲉⲣⲁⲧⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲩϩⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ⲉⲛⲥⲃⲧⲱⲧ ⲛⲛⲁⲩ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲉⲡⲓⲥϭⲏⲣ ⲛϩⲁⲡⲗⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲧⲉⲟⲩⲁ ⲛⲟⲩⲱⲧ ⲡⲉ ·
Translation: Therefore, O my beloved, what is meet for us to do is this: We must act in such a way that we may find ourselves prepared at any hour, and we must sail a straightforward course, and always in the same direction;

Verse: ⲙⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛⲕⲧⲟⲛ ⲛⲕⲉⲥⲟⲡ ⲛⲧⲛⲕⲁⲧⲟⲣⲑⲟⲩ ⲙⲡⲉⲛⲧⲁⲛ ⲁⲙⲉⲗⲉⲓ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ·
Translation: for it is unlikely that we shall be able to turn back again and cultivate successfully that concerning which we have been careless.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲛⲥⲃⲧⲱⲧ ⲛⲛⲁⲩ ⲛⲓⲙ ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲛⲁϫⲟⲟⲥ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲡⲁⲣⲣⲏⲥⲓⲁ ϫⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲡⲁϩⲏⲧ ⲥⲃⲧⲱⲧ ⲡⲁϩⲏⲧ ⲥⲃⲧⲱⲧ :
Translation: Let us therefore be prepared at any hour, so that we may say with boldness, ' Lord, my heart is ready, my heart is ready.’

Verse: ⲧⲛϣⲟⲟⲡ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲛⲟϭ ⲙⲡⲟⲗⲉⲙⲟⲥ ϩⲙⲡⲉⲓⲃⲓⲟⲥ ·
Translation: ’ In this life we are in a mighty war.

Verse: ⲁⲛⲣⲉϥⲣⲛⲟⲃⲉ ⲉⲧⲉⲛⲇⲁⲓⲙⲱⲛ ⲛⲉⲁⲩⲥⲱⲙⲛⲧ ⲛⲧⲉⲩⲡⲓⲧⲉ ·
Translation: The workers of evil, who are the demons, stretch their bows.

Verse: ⲟⲩⲁ ⲙⲉⲛ ⲉϥⲛⲉϫⲥⲟⲟⲧⲉ ⲉⲛⲉⲛⲙⲁⲁϫⲉ
Translation: Then one of them shooteth an arrow into our ears, so that we may listen to slanderous chatterings with pleasure.

Verse: ⲕⲉⲟⲩⲁ ⲉⲛⲉⲛⲃⲁⲗ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛϭⲱϣⲧ ⲕⲁⲕⲱⲥ · ⲛⲥⲁⲛⲉⲧⲉⲙⲉϣϣⲉ ·
Translation: And another shooteth an arrow into our eyes, so that we may turn our gaze in a wrongful manner towards the things which are unseemly.

Verse: ⲕⲉⲟⲩⲁ ⲉϥⲛⲟⲩϫⲉ ⲉⲡⲉⲛⲗⲁⲥ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛϣⲱⲥ ⲙⲡⲉⲛⲥⲟⲛ ·
Translation: And another shooteth an arrow into our tongue, so as to make us to revile scornfully our brother.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲕⲉⲟⲩⲁ ⲉϥⲛⲟⲩϫⲉ ⲉⲛⲉⲛⲙⲁϩⲧ ⲉϥⲉⲣⲏⲑⲓⲍⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲙⲛⲧⲟⲩⲉⲙϩⲁϩ ·
Translation: And another shooteth an arrow into our belly, which exciteth in us the appetite of gluttony.

Verse: ⲕⲉⲟⲩⲁ ⲇⲉ ⲉⲛⲉⲛϭⲓϫ ⲉϥⲥⲱⲕ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ ⲉⲩⲙⲛⲧⲣⲉϥⲧⲱⲣⲡ
Translation: And another shooteth an arrow into our hands, which leadeth us on to deeds of rapine, and greed of the most excessive character.

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲛⲁⲓ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ⲉⲣⲉⲡⲙⲁⲕⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲡⲁⲩⲗⲟⲥ ⲱⲣϫ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ ·
Translation: Because of all these things the blessed man Paul armed us with weapons,

Verse: ⲁϥⲥϩⲁⲓ ϫⲉϫⲓ ⲛⲏⲧⲛ ⲛⲧⲡⲁⲛϩⲟⲡⲗⲓⲁ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ · ⲙⲛⲧⲡⲉⲣⲓⲕⲉⲫⲁⲗⲁⲓⲁ ⲙⲡⲉⲡⲛⲉⲩⲙⲁ ·
Translation: for he wrote saying, 'Take unto you the whole armour of God, and the helmet of the Spirit.

Verse: ⲛⲁⲓ
Translation: With these ye shall be able to quench every fiery dart of the Evil One'

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲥⲱⲧⲉⲙ ⲛⲥⲁⲧⲉ ⲥⲙⲏ ⲙⲡⲉⲡⲣⲟⲫⲏⲧⲏⲥ ⲉⲧϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲁⲩⲧⲁⲙⲟⲕ ⲡⲣⲱⲙⲉ ϫⲉⲟⲩ ⲡⲉⲧⲛⲁⲛⲟⲩϥ ·
Translation: Let us hearken unto the voice of the prophet, which saith, ' He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good ;

Verse: ⲏ ⲟⲩ ⲡⲉⲧⲉⲣⲉⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ϣⲓⲛⲉ ⲛⲥⲱϥ ⲛⲧⲟⲟⲧⲕ · ⲛⲥⲁⲧⲣⲉⲕⲉⲓⲣⲉ ⲙⲡϩⲁⲡ ⲙⲛⲧⲇⲓⲕⲁⲓⲟⲥⲩⲛⲏ ·
Translation: and also that which God seeketh after at thy hands, to make thyself to perform judgement and righteousness.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲛⲅⲙⲉⲣⲉⲡⲛⲁ · ⲛⲅⲥⲃⲧⲱⲧ ⲉⲟⲩⲁϩⲕ
Translation: And thou shalt love mercy, and to prepare to follow closely after the Lord thy God.'

Verse: ϩⲉⲛⲥⲟⲡ ⲇⲉ ⲟⲛ ⲉϥϯⲥⲃⲱ ⲛⲁⲛ ⲉⲧⲙⲛⲧⲥⲧⲙⲏⲧ · ⲉϥⲉⲣⲏⲧ ⲛⲟⲩⲃⲉⲕⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲧⲛⲁⲥⲱⲧⲙ ⲛⲥⲱϥ ·
Translation: and sometimes He teacheth us obedience, and He bestoweth rewards upon those who hearken unto Him.

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲓ ⲉⲁⲛⲙⲟⲩⲣ ⲛⲛϯⲡⲉ ⲙⲡⲉⲛϩⲏⲧ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲙⲉ
Translation: Therefore we must gird up the loins of our heart(s) in truth.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲣⲡⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲛⲧⲁϥϣⲟⲡⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧⲛ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ·
Translation: Let us keep in remembrance all the things which He suffered for our sakes.

Verse: ⲁⲩϫⲡⲟϥ ϩⲱⲥ ⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧⲛ ·
Translation: He was made after the manner of a man for our sakes. He was suckled at the breast like a man.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲥⲁⲛⲟⲩϣϥ ϩⲱⲥ ⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲁϥⲣⲕⲟⲩⲓ ϩⲛⲑⲩⲗⲏⲕⲓⲁ ·
Translation: He was suckled at the breast like a man. He made Himself to be a child in age (or, stature).

Verse: ⲁϥϫⲓⲃⲁⲡⲧⲓⲥⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲃⲏⲏⲧⲛ ·
Translation: He received baptism for our sakes.

Verse: ⲁϥϩⲕⲟ · ⲁϥⲛⲕⲟⲧⲕ ⲁϥⲱⲃϣ
Translation: He suffered hunger. He slept, He slumbered for our sakes.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ϭⲉ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲛⲛⲁⲩ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲉⲡⲉⲛⲧⲁϥϩⲩⲡⲟⲙⲓⲛⲉ ⲉⲛⲁⲓ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ ϩⲁⲛⲉⲛⲛⲟⲃⲉ ·
Translation: Let us, then, think at all times on all these things which He suffered patiently for the sake of our sins,

Verse: ⲙⲡⲁⲧⲉⲧⲛⲡⲱϩ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲉⲡⲙⲁ ⲙⲡⲉⲥⲛⲟϥ ·
Translation: (and) that (the Book) saith, Ye have not yet resisted unto blood, (striving against sin).'

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲉⲧⲉⲧⲛⲁⲅⲱⲛⲓⲍⲉ ⲟⲩⲃⲉⲡⲛⲟⲃⲉ ⲉⲧⲉⲡⲁⲓ ⲡⲉ ϫⲉⲥⲉⲁⲡⲉⲧⲉⲓ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ
Translation: But ye shall fight against sin, that is to say, although we are not now asked to give our blood for the sake of Christ,

Verse: ⲛⲃⲗⲗⲉ ⲁϥⲧⲣⲉⲩⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ · ⲙⲛⲛⲕⲟⲟⲩⲉ ⲧⲏⲣⲟⲩ
Translation: He made the blind to see, besides all these other healiugs which we put aside and do not attempt and describe one by one.

Verse: ⲕⲁⲧⲁⲡⲉⲙϣⲁ ⲙⲡⲧⲟⲡⲟⲥ ⲉⲛⲧⲁⲩⲥϩⲁⲓ ⲡⲉⲛⲣⲁⲛ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ·
Translation: in a manner suitable for the place wherein our names are inscribed.

Verse: ⲛⲧⲁⲧⲉⲕⲣⲁⲫⲏ ⲙⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ϫⲉϣⲙⲙⲟ ϩⲓⲣⲙⲛϭⲟⲓⲗⲉ · ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲛⲁⲕⲁⲧⲁⲫⲣⲟⲛⲉⲓ ⲛⲛⲁⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ :
Translation: Now the Scripture hath called us ' strangers and sojourners ', so that we may think scorn of the things of this place (i. e., world).

Verse: ⲉⲣⲉⲧϩⲏⲇⲟⲛⲏ ⲧⲛⲧⲱⲛ ⲉⲩⲟⲩϩⲟⲣ ·
Translation: The pleasure of this world is like unto a day (Coptic reads: dog):

Verse: ⲉⲕϣⲁⲛⲇⲓⲱⲕⲉ
Translation: if we chase him away, he fleeth; and if we feed him, he will abide with thee.

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲓ ⲁⲓⲁⲕⲕⲱⲃⲟⲥ ϫⲟⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲁϩⲉⲣⲁⲧⲧⲏⲩⲧⲛ
Translation: It is for this reason that Aiakk6bos (James) said, 'Resist ye the j Devil, and he shall flee from you.'

Verse: ⲙⲡⲣⲧⲣⲉⲛⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ϫⲉⲟⲩⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛⲙⲉⲧⲁⲛⲟⲉⲓ
Translation: Let us not think in our minds that we shall be able to repent in Amente,

Verse: ⲡⲡⲁϩⲣⲉ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲛⲧⲙⲉⲧⲁⲛⲟⲓⲁ
Translation: for the medicine of repentance hath no effect in that place.

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲕⲁⲛ
Translation: For although we shall gnash with our teeth, and our tongue shall be on fire, there shall be in that place none who shall dip his finger in water for us;

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲧⲛⲛⲁⲥⲱⲧⲙ ϩⲱⲱⲛ ⲉⲛϣⲁϫⲉ ⲉⲛⲧⲁⲡⲉⲓⲣⲙⲙⲁⲟ ⲥⲟⲧⲙⲟⲩ ·
Translation: on the contrary, we ourselves shall hear the words which the rich man heard.

Verse: ⲉⲁⲛⲉⲓⲙⲉ ϭⲉ ⲱ ⲛⲁⲙⲉⲣⲁⲧⲉ ϫⲉⲛⲉϩⲃⲏⲩⲉ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ ϣⲟⲃⲉ ⲁⲛ ϩⲉⲛⲣⲁⲥⲟⲩ · ⲁⲩⲱ ϫⲉⲉⲛϣⲟⲟⲡ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲡⲁⲛⲇⲟⲕⲓⲟⲛ · ⲉϩⲁⲡⲥ ⲡⲉ ⲡⲁⲛⲧⲱⲥ ⲧⲣⲉⲛⲉⲓ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲛϩⲏⲧϥ ·
Translation: Let us know, then, O my beloved, that the works of this changing (world) are nothing but phantasms (or, dreams), and that we live in a house wherein travellers are received, out from which we must go forth in any case.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛϥⲓⲡⲣⲟⲟⲩϣ ⲛⲧⲉϩⲓⲏ ⲙⲛⲛⲉⲫⲟⲧⲓⲟⲛ ⲉⲧⲉϣⲁⲛϫⲓⲧⲟⲩ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ⲉⲧⲉϩⲓⲏ ·
Translation: Let us take care concerning the road, and concerning the provisions which we must take with us on the road.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛϯϩⲓⲱⲱⲛ ⲛϩⲉⲛϩⲟⲓⲧⲉ ⲉⲛⲏⲩ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲙⲡⲉⲓⲃⲓⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲓ ⲉⲛⲧⲁⲡⲁⲩⲗⲟⲥ ⲥⲩⲙⲃⲟⲩⲗⲉⲩⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ⲛⲁⲛ ⲉϥϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ϫⲉϯ ϩⲓⲱⲧⲧⲏⲩⲧⲛ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲥⲡⲗⲁⲅⲭⲛⲟⲛ ⲙⲙⲛⲧϣⲁⲛⲁϩⲧⲏϥ ⲛⲟⲩⲙⲛⲧⲭⲣⲏⲥⲧⲟⲥ ⲙⲛⲟⲩⲑⲃⲃⲓⲟ ·
Translation: Let us array ourselves in the garments which appertain to this life, concerning which Paul counselled us, saying, 'Dress yourselves in the bowels of mercies, and in goodness, and in humility'

Verse: ⲧⲛⲣⲭⲣⲉⲓⲁ ⲁⲛ ⲛⲟⲩⲛⲟⲩⲃ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ · ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲟⲩⲧⲗϯⲗⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ⲧⲉⲧⲛⲣⲭⲣⲉⲓⲁ ⲛⲁⲥ ·
Translation: In that place we shall have no need of gold, but we shall have need of the dropping of water.

Verse: ⲧⲛⲣⲭⲣⲉⲓⲁ ⲁⲛ ⲛϩⲉⲛϭⲱⲃⲉ ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ϩⲉⲛⲕⲁⲣⲡⲟⲥ · ⲧⲛⲣⲭⲣⲉⲓⲁ ⲁⲛ ⲛϩⲉⲛϣⲁϫⲉ ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ϩⲉⲛϩⲃⲏⲩⲉ ·
Translation: We shall have no need of the leaves of trees and plants, but of the fruit thereof. We shall have no need of words, but of deeds.

Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲅⲁⲣ ϫⲉⲟⲩⲟⲛ ⲛⲓⲙ ⲁⲛ ⲉⲧϫⲱ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲓ ϫⲉⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲡϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲡⲉⲧⲛⲁⲃⲱⲕ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲧⲙⲛⲧⲣⲣⲟ ⲛⲙⲡⲏⲩⲉ · ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲡⲉⲧⲛⲁⲉⲓⲣⲉ ⲙⲡⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲙⲡⲁⲉⲓⲱⲧ ⲉⲧϩⲛⲙⲡⲏⲩⲉ ·
Translation: For He (i. e., Christ) said, ' It is not every one who shall say unto Me, Lord, Lord, that shall enter into the kingdom of heaven, but he who doeth the Will of My Father which (is) in heaven/

Verse: ⲙⲡⲣⲧⲣⲉⲛⲁⲡⲁⲧⲁ ϭⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ ⲙⲙⲓⲛⲙⲙⲟⲛ ·
Translation: Let us therefore by no manner of means deceive ourselves.

Verse: ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ ⲙⲉⲛ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲛⲁⲅⲁⲑⲟⲛ ⲙⲛⲙⲡⲉⲧϩⲟⲟⲩ ⲟⲩⲛⲧⲁⲩ ⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲙⲡⲉⲩϫⲱⲕ ·
Translation: For in this world both the good things and the evil things which are therein fulfil themselves.

Verse: ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ ⲇⲉ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ϩⲉⲛⲁⲅⲁⲑⲟⲛ ⲛⲉ ⲉⲩⲙⲏⲛ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϣⲁⲉⲛⲉϩ ⲙⲛϩⲉⲛⲕⲟⲗⲁⲥⲓⲥ ⲛⲁⲧⲟⲩⲱ ·
Translation: In that world, however, the good things endure, and exist for ever and for ever, and the punishments are endless.

Verse: ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ ⲕⲁⲛ ⲉⲣϣⲁⲛⲡⲥⲱⲙⲁ ⲣⲱⲕϩ · ϣⲁⲣⲉⲧⲉⲯⲩⲭⲏ ⲉⲓ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ
Translation: In this world, if the body burnetii, the soul cometh forth therefrom, and it existeth undestroyed.

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲙⲉⲛ ⲉϣϥⲓ ϩⲁⲡⲁⲏⲣ ⲛⲟⲩⲥⲓⲟⲟⲩⲛⲉ ⲉⲩϣⲁⲛⲧⲙϩⲟⲥ ⲉⲡⲉϩⲟⲩⲟ ⲡⲁⲣⲁⲡⲉⲧⲉϣϣⲉ · ⲉⲓⲉ ⲉⲛⲁⲣⲟⲩ ⲉⲩϣⲁⲛⲡⲁⲣⲁⲇⲓⲇⲟⲩ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ ⲉⲡⲓⲉⲣⲟ ⲛⲕⲱϩⲧ ⲉⲧⲥⲱⲕ ϩⲓⲧϩⲏ ⲙⲡⲃⲏⲙⲁ ⲙⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ·
Translation: If a man be unable to bear the heat of the bath which hath been heated to an unwonted degree, what will he do when he is delivered over to the river of fire which floweth before the throne of Christ?

Verse: ϩⲁⲡⲥ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲡⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲩⲇⲟⲕⲓⲙⲁⲍⲉ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲛ ⲛⲓⲙ ϩⲓⲧⲙⲡⲕⲱϩⲧ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ·
Translation: It is necessary that every man should make himself to consider the fire which is there.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲙⲟⲩϣⲧ ⲛⲧⲉⲥⲫⲣⲁⲅⲓⲥ ϫⲉⲉⲛⲉϥⲟⲩⲟϫ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲉⲛⲛⲟⲩϥ
Translation: Let us examine carefully the seal which is on our gold and see that it is intact, lest peradventure some come and plunder our treasure.

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲁϥⲣⲓⲙⲉ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲉⲡⲣⲟⲫⲏⲧⲏⲥ ⲓⲉⲣⲏⲙⲓⲁⲥ ⲉϫⲙⲡϣⲟⲣϣⲣ
Translation: If the prophet Jeremiah wept over the overthrow of the temple, which had been built throughout with stones of price, saying, ' Leave me alone, let me weep bitterly,' how much more is it right for us to weep over the temple of ourselves, which is exceedingly glorious,

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲉⲛϣⲁⲛⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲟⲩⲁ ⲉⲁϥⲙⲟⲩ ϣⲁⲛⲣⲓⲙⲉ
Translation: If we look upon one who is dead, we weep over him according to custom, what man is there who would be altogether so foolish as not to weep for his own soul if it had died in sin?

Verse: ⲁⲣⲓⲡⲙⲉⲉⲩⲉ ϫⲉⲁⲡⲕⲁⲓⲣⲟⲥ ϩⲱⲛ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ·
Translation: Remember thou, then, that the time hath drawn nigh,

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ϭⲉ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲁⲡϩⲓⲛⲏⲃ ⲛⲛⲣⲁⲥⲟⲩ · ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲉⲓⲣⲉ ⲛϩⲉⲛⲕⲁⲣⲡⲟⲥ ⲉⲩⲙϣⲁ ⲛⲧⲙⲉⲧⲁⲛⲟⲓⲁ · ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲉⲧⲥⲏϩ
Translation: Let us rise up out of the slumber of dreams, and let us make (or, bring forth) fruits worthy of repentance, even as it is written.

Verse: ⲧⲙⲉⲧⲁⲛⲟⲓⲁ ⲉⲥⲡⲏϩ ⲁⲛ ϣⲁⲁⲟⲩⲭⲣⲟⲛⲟⲥ ·
Translation: Repentance requireth not a long time, and very many of the martyrs received the crown for (the repentance) of a short time.

Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲡⲁⲧⲉⲫⲩⲥⲓⲥ ⲛⲛⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲡⲉ ϩⲱⲱⲗⲉ ϩⲛⲟⲩϩⲱⲃ ·
Translation: And moreover, it belongeth to the nature of men to go astray in the work,

Verse: ⲟⲩϩⲱⲃ ⲇⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲡⲥⲁⲧⲁⲛⲁⲥ ⲡⲉ ⲙⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ
Translation: but it is the work of Satan to persist in the going astray.

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲁⲓ ⲁⲡⲉⲛϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲱϣ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ϩⲓⲧⲙⲡⲉⲡⲣⲟⲫⲏⲧⲏⲥ ϫⲉⲙⲏ ⲙⲛⲥⲟⲛⲧⲉ ϩⲛⲕⲁⲗⲁⲁⲇ ·
Translation: For this reason our God cried out to us through the prophet saying, 'Is there no balsam in Gilead?

Verse: ⲏ ⲙⲛⲥⲁⲉⲓⲛ ϩⲙⲡⲙⲁ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ·
Translation: Or is there no physician in that place?

Verse: ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲟⲩ ⲙⲡϥⲉⲓ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲛϭⲓⲡⲧⲁⲗϭⲟ ⲛⲧϣⲉⲉⲣⲉ ⲙⲡⲁⲗⲁⲟⲥ ·
Translation: Why then hath not the healing of the daughter of my people increased?'

Verse: ⲉⲓⲧⲁ ⲉⲣϣⲁⲛⲟⲩⲙⲉⲗⲟⲥ ⲙⲉⲛ ϣⲱⲛⲉ ϩⲙⲡⲉⲛⲥⲱⲙⲁ ·
Translation: If it should happen that any member in our body become diseased, are we not wont to send for the physicians, and to make all the haste possible until we have healed that sick member in our body?

Verse: ⲧⲉⲛⲯⲩⲭⲏ ⲇⲉ ϩⲱⲱⲥ ϣⲱⲛⲉ ⲧⲛⲁⲙⲉⲗⲉⲓ ⲉⲣⲟⲥ · ⲁⲩⲱ ⲧⲛϥⲓⲣⲟⲟⲩϣ ⲁⲛ ϩⲁⲡⲉⲥⲟⲩϫⲁⲓ ⲉⲡⲧⲏⲣϥ ·
Translation: When, however, the soul itself is sick we are careless about it, and we take no care whatsoever about the healing thereof.

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲣϩⲟⲧⲉ ϩⲏⲧϥ ⲙⲡⲉⲧⲉⲩⲛϣϭⲟⲙ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ⲉⲧⲁⲕⲟ
Translation: Let us hold in fear Him that hath the power to destroy our soul and our body in Gehenna.

Verse: ϥⲁϩⲉⲣⲁⲧϥ ⲛϭⲓⲡϣⲱⲥ ⲉⲧⲛⲁⲛⲟⲩϥ ⲉϥⲟⲩⲱϣ ⲉⲧⲱⲣⲡ ⲛⲛⲉⲛⲯⲩⲭⲏ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲛⲧⲧⲁⲡⲣⲟ ⲙⲡⲙⲟⲩⲓ ϩⲁⲧϩⲏ ⲉⲙⲡⲁⲧϥⲟⲩⲱⲙⲕ ⲙⲙⲟⲟⲩ ·
Translation: The Good Shepherd standeth wishing to snatch away our souls from out of the mouth of the lion before he is able to devour them.

Verse: ϥϫⲓϣⲕⲁⲕ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ϩⲱⲱⲛ ϫⲉⲡⲁϣⲏⲣⲉ ⲁⲕⲣⲛⲟⲃⲉ ⲙⲡⲣⲟⲩⲱϩ ⲉⲧⲟⲟⲧⲕ ·
Translation: He crieth out unto us ourselves saying, 'My son, thou hast sinned; do not (sin) again'

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ϫⲉⲙⲏ ⲡⲉ ϣⲁϥϩⲉ ⲙⲉϥⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ·
Translation: And again He saith, Shall not he who falleth rise up again?

Verse: ⲏ ⲡⲉ
Translation: Or shall not he who hath gone astray turn again into the right way?'

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ϫⲉⲕⲧⲉⲧⲏⲩⲧⲛ
Translation: And again He saith, 'Turn ye yourselves unto Me, My children (or, sons) who have wandered afar off, and I will heal your wounds of contrition.'

Verse: ϥϫⲓϭⲟⲗ ⲁⲛ ⲛϭⲓⲓⲡⲉⲛⲧⲁϥϫⲟⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲛⲧⲁⲓⲉⲓ ⲁⲛ ⲉⲕⲣⲓⲛⲉ ⲙⲡⲕⲟⲥⲙⲟⲥ · ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲣⲉⲡⲕⲟⲥⲙⲟⲥ ⲟⲩϫⲁⲓ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲓⲧⲟⲟⲧ ·
Translation: He was no liar who said, 'I have not come to judge the world, but in order that the world might have salvation through Me'

Verse: ⲙⲟⲛⲟⲛ ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲙⲉⲧⲁⲛⲟⲉⲓ ·
Translation: The one thing for us to do is to repent.

Verse: ϯⲟⲩⲉϣⲡⲙⲟⲩ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲁⲛ ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲙⲡⲣⲉϥⲣⲛⲟⲃⲉ
Translation: For He saith, 'I do not desire the death of the sinner, but that he would turn himself from his evil way, and live'

Verse: ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲉⲧⲉⲣⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲙⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲯⲩⲭⲏ ⲉⲧⲛⲁⲙⲉⲧⲁⲛⲟⲉⲓ
Translation: as that in which God loveth the soul which repenteth.

Verse: ⲟⲩϯⲙⲓⲛⲉ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲧⲉ ⲧⲙⲛⲧⲙⲁⲓⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: For the lovingkindness of God towards man is in this wise:

Verse: ⲉⲙⲉϥⲕⲧⲟϥ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲉⲛⲉϩ ⲙⲡⲉⲧⲛⲁϯ ⲙⲡⲉϥⲛⲟⲩⲟⲓ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲙⲉⲧⲁⲛⲟⲓⲁ
Translation: He never rejecteth him that setteth forth to come to Him with repentance.

Verse: ⲕⲁⲛ ⲉⲁϥϩⲉ
Translation: And if he hath fallen into the ditch, and into evil, yet will He stretch out widely His hands to him saying, ' Turn thou to Me, and I will save thee'

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲟⲩ ⲛⲥⲁⲉⲓⲛ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲕⲁⲛ ⲉⲥϣⲁⲛϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲡⲉⲧϣⲱⲛⲉ ⲣϩⲏⲧ ϣⲏⲙ ⲛⲉϥϣⲱⲥ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ·
Translation: Doth there exist a physician who, supposing it to be his wish to make him that is sick to recover a little, would reproach him

Verse: ⲙⲁⲣⲉⲡⲥⲁⲉⲓⲛ ⲕⲁⲧⲁⲫⲣⲟⲛⲉⲓ ⲙⲙⲟϥ · ⲟⲩⲇⲉ ⲙⲉϥⲧⲱⲱⲃⲉ ⲛⲁϥ ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲛϣⲱⲥ · ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ϣⲁϥϯⲡⲁϩⲣⲉ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ϩⲛⲟⲩⲙⲛⲧⲣⲙⲣⲁϣ ·
Translation: The physician doth not treat him with contempt, neither doth he award him the just retribution for his disgraceful state, but he administereth unto him the medicine with gentleness.

Verse: ⲡⲟⲥⲟ ⲙⲁⲗⲗⲟⲛ ⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ⲛⲁⲅⲁⲑⲟⲥ ⲡⲥⲁⲉⲓⲛ ⲙⲙⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲛⲯⲩⲭⲏ ·
Translation: How much more then shall God, Who is in truth the Good Physician of our souls (act thus towards us)?

Verse: ⲙⲟⲛⲟⲛ ⲙⲡⲣⲧⲣⲉⲛⲉⲓⲁⲧⲟⲟⲧⲛ ⲛⲥⲁⲡⲉⲛⲟⲩϫⲁⲓ ⲙⲙⲓⲛⲙⲙⲟⲛ ·
Translation: Above all things let us not despair of our own salvation.

Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲡⲟⲗⲗⲁⲕⲓⲥ ϣⲁⲣⲉⲡϣⲟⲉⲓϫ ϩⲉ ϩⲙⲡⲁⲅⲱⲛ ⲉⲡϩⲁⲉ ⲛϥⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ⲛϥϫⲓⲕⲗⲟⲙ ·
Translation: For he who contendeth in the games is wont to fall down often, but in the end he riseth up, and receiveththe crown of victory.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲡⲙⲁⲧⲟⲓ ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲁⲧⲣⲉⲩⲡⲗⲏⲅⲏ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ⲛⲥⲉⲑⲉⲣⲁⲡⲉⲩⲉ ⲙⲙⲟϥ · ⲛϥⲡⲟⲗⲉⲙⲉⲓ ⲛⲕⲉⲥⲟⲡ ⲛϥⲉⲩⲇⲟⲕⲉⲓⲙⲉⲓ ⲛϩⲟⲩⲟ ⲉⲛⲉⲧⲉⲙⲡⲟⲩϫⲟⲧⲟⲩ ⲉⲡⲧⲏⲣϥ ·
Translation: So also is it with the soldier. After he hath been wounded (the physicians) heal him, and he wageth war again, and men consider him to be of greater value than those who have not been wounded at all.

Verse: ⲁⲩⲱ ⲟⲩ ⲛϩⲁϩ ⲛⲉϣⲱⲧ ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲁⲧⲣⲉⲡϫⲟⲓ ⲱⲙⲥ ⲛⲥⲉϯⲟⲥⲉ ⲙⲡⲉⲩⲁⲩⲉⲓⲛ ⲙⲉⲩⲕⲁⲧⲟⲟⲧⲟⲩ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ·
Translation: Similarly also there are very many merchants who, although their ships have foundered, and they have lost their cargoes, do not despair,

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ϣⲁⲩⲕⲧⲟⲟⲩ ⲉⲧⲉⲩⲉⲓ ⲉⲡϣⲱⲧ ⲛⲕⲉⲥⲟⲡ ⲛⲥⲉⲣⲣⲙⲙⲁⲟ ·
Translation: but they go back again regularly to the markets,

Verse: ⲙⲏ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲡⲕⲱϩⲧ ⲛⲧⲅⲉϩⲉⲛⲛⲁ ⲛⲧⲁⲩⲥⲃⲧⲱⲧϥ ⲛⲁⲛ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ · ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲛⲧⲁⲩⲥⲃⲧⲱⲧϥ ⲙⲡⲇⲓⲁⲃⲟⲗⲟⲥ ⲙⲛⲛⲉϥⲁⲅⲅⲉⲗⲟⲥ ·
Translation: For the burning fire of Gehenna hath not been prepared solely for us, but it was made ready for the Devil and his angels.

Verse: ⲙⲟⲛⲟⲛ ⲙⲡⲣⲧⲣⲉⲛϫⲉⲣⲟ ⲙⲡⲕⲱϩⲧ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ⲙⲁⲩⲁⲁⲛ · ⲛⲧⲛⲥⲱⲧⲙ ϩⲱⲱϥ ⲟⲛ ϫⲉⲃⲱⲕ ϩⲙⲡϣⲁϩ ⲉⲛⲧⲁⲧⲉⲧⲛ ϫⲉⲣⲱϥ ·
Translation: Above all things let us not kindle that fire for ourselves, and let us not hear besides the words, (Get ye into the fire which ye yourselves have kindled)

Verse: ⲙⲛⲗⲁⲁⲩ ⲇⲉ ⲛϣⲱⲛⲉ ⲟ ⲛⲁⲧⲧⲁⲗϭⲟ ⲛⲁϩⲣⲙⲡⲡⲁϩⲣⲉ ⲙⲡⲥⲁⲉⲓⲛ ⲛⲛⲉⲛⲯⲩⲭⲏ ·
Translation: There is no sick man living who cannot be healed by the medicine of the Physician of our souls.

Verse: ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲙⲉϣⲁⲕ ⲕⲛⲁϫⲟⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲙⲛϣϭⲟⲙ ⲙⲙⲟⲓ ⲉⲡⲱϩ ⲉⲧⲙⲛⲧⲧⲉⲗⲓⲟⲥ ·
Translation: But perhaps thou wilt say, ' I certainly cannot attain unto perfection.'

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲙⲛϣϭⲟⲙ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ⲉⲡⲱϩ ⲉⲧⲙⲛⲧⲧⲉⲗⲓⲟⲥ · ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲙⲛϣϭⲟⲙ ⲙⲙⲟⲕ ⲉϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲙⲡⲣⲏ ⲕⲁⲛ ⲣⲧϩⲉ ⲛⲛⲥⲓⲟⲩ ·
Translation: If thou art not able to attain unto perfection, and if thou art not able to become like a sun, then make thyself to be like unto a star.

Verse: ⲙⲟⲛⲟⲛ ⲡⲱⲱⲛⲉ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ϩⲙⲡⲕⲁϩ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ⲉⲧⲡⲉ · ⲛⲅⲧⲟⲛⲧⲛ ⲉⲛⲥⲓⲟⲩ · ⲉⲧⲟ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓⲛ ·
Translation: In any case transfer thyself from earth to heaven. Make thyself to be like a star which sendeth forth light.

Verse: ⲡⲟⲥⲟ ⲙⲁⲗⲗⲟⲛ ϥⲛⲁϯⲃⲉⲕⲉ ⲛⲁⲛ ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲛⲉⲛϩⲃⲏⲩⲉ ⲉⲧⲛⲁⲛⲟⲩⲟⲩ ⲕⲁⲛ ⲉϩⲉⲛⲕⲟⲩⲓ ⲛⲉ ·
Translation: how much more shall He give us wages for our good works, even though they be very few?

Verse: ⲟⲩⲕ ⲟⲩⲛ ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲙⲟⲕϩ ⲛⲟⲩⲕⲟⲩⲓ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓϣ · ϫⲉⲕⲁⲥ ⲉⲛⲉⲛϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲉⲛⲟ ⲛϩⲁⲉ ⲉⲡⲱⲛϩ ⲛϣⲁⲉⲛⲉϩ ·
Translation: Therefore let us labour for a little time, so that we may at last live the life which is for ever.

Verse: ⲉⲛⲉⲩⲛϣϭⲟⲙ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲡⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛⲙⲟⲩ ⲛⲟⲩⲙⲏⲏϣⲉ ⲛⲥⲟⲡ ⲡⲉⲧⲉϣϣⲉ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ⲡⲉ ⲉⲧⲣⲉⲛⲣⲡⲁⲓ · ϣⲁⲛⲧⲛⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲡⲉⲭⲣⲓⲥⲧⲟⲥ ⲉϥⲛⲏⲩ ϩⲙⲡⲉϥⲉⲟⲟⲩ ·
Translation: If it were possible for us to die many, many times, it would be seemly for us to do so, so that we might see Christ coming in His glory.

Verse: ⲉⲛⲁⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ⲁⲛ ϩⲓⲧⲛⲟⲩⲁⲓⲛⲓⲅⲙⲁ · ⲁⲗⲗⲁ ⲉⲛⲁⲑⲉⲱⲣⲉⲓ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ⲟⲛ ⲛⲧϩⲉ ⲉⲧϥϣⲟⲟⲡ ⲙⲙⲟⲥ · ϩⲛⲛⲉⲛⲃⲁⲗ ⲙⲙⲓⲛⲙⲙⲟⲛ ⲕⲁⲧⲁⲧⲙⲛⲧⲙⲛⲧⲣⲉ ⲙⲡⲁⲡⲟⲥⲧⲟⲗⲟⲥ ⲓⲱϩⲁⲛⲛⲏⲥ ⲡⲣⲉϥϣⲁϫⲉ ⲉⲧⲃⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: We shall not see Him in a riddle, but we shall | see Him as He really is, with our own eyes, according to the testimony of the Apostle John, who preached concerning God.

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲉⲛϣⲁⲛⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲡⲥⲁ ⲛⲟⲩⲥⲱⲙⲁ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ ϣⲁⲛⲣϣⲡⲏⲣⲉ ⲙⲙⲟϥ ·
Translation: If we look upon the beauty of the human body in this place (i. e., world) we are wont to marvel thereat.

Verse: ⲕⲁⲓ ⲧⲟ ⲡⲥⲁ ⲛⲛⲥⲱⲙⲁ ⲟⲩ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ ⲡⲉ ϩⲛϩⲉⲛⲭⲩⲙⲟⲥ · ⲙⲛϩⲉⲛⲫⲗⲉⲕⲙⲁ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲙⲛⲛⲥⲁⲡⲙⲟⲩ ϣⲁⲩⲕⲁⲧⲁⲛⲧⲁ ⲉⲩϥⲛⲧ ⲙⲛⲟⲩⲕⲣⲙⲉⲥ ⲙⲛⲟⲩⲧⲟⲉⲓⲧ ·
Translation: Now the beauty of human bodies ariseth from humours and from heat, which after death turn into worms, and ashes, and corruption.

Verse: ⲡⲟⲥⲟ ⲙⲁⲗⲗⲟⲛ ⲉⲛϣⲁⲛⲑⲉⲱⲣⲉⲓ ⲙⲡⲥⲁ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ⲛⲁⲧⲧⲁⲕⲟ · ⲛⲁⲧϫⲃⲓⲛ ⲛⲁⲧⲧⲱⲗⲙ ·
Translation: How much more, then, shall we admire when we look upon that beauty which is incorruptible, and spotless, and pure?

Verse: ⲛⲧⲁⲡⲉⲧⲣⲟⲥ ⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲩⲕⲟⲩⲓ ⲛⲟⲩⲟⲉⲓⲛ ϣⲏⲙ ⲙⲙⲁⲧⲉ ⲛⲧⲉⲡⲉϥⲉⲟⲟⲩ ·
Translation: Since Peter, when he saw only the very smallest portion of the light of the glory

Verse: ⲡⲉϫⲁϥ ⲛⲁⲛ ϫⲉⲛⲁⲛⲟⲩⲥ ⲛⲁⲛ ⲉϭⲱ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ ·
Translation: thereof, said, 'It is good for us to remain in this place'

Verse: ⲟⲩ ⲁⲣⲁ ⲡⲉⲧⲛϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲙⲙⲟⲛ ϩⲟⲧⲁⲛ ⲉⲛϣⲁⲛⲑⲉⲱⲣⲉⲓ ⲙⲡⲉⲟⲟⲩ ⲧⲏⲣϥ ⲉⲧⲙⲙⲁⲩ ·
Translation: what shall happen unto us when we shall look upon the fullness of that glory?

Verse: ⲉϣϫⲉ ϣⲁⲛⲙⲁⲅⲁⲣⲓⲍⲉ ⲛⲛⲉⲧϩⲏⲛ ⲉϩⲟⲩⲛ ⲉⲡⲣⲣⲟ ⲙⲡⲉⲓⲙⲁ ⲉⲛϣⲁⲛⲛⲁⲩ ⲉⲣⲟϥ ⲉϥⲡⲣⲟⲗⲑⲉ ϩⲓϫⲙⲡⲟⲭⲏⲙⲁ ⲛⲛⲟⲩⲃ · ⲉϥⲫⲟⲣⲉⲓ ⲙⲡⲉⲕⲗⲟⲙ ⲙⲛⲧⲡⲟⲣⲫⲏⲣⲁ · ⲉⲓⲉ ⲉⲛⲁϣⲱⲡⲉ ⲙⲙⲁⲅⲁⲣⲓⲟⲥ ⲛⲟⲩⲏⲣ ⲉⲩϣⲁⲛⲧⲁϩⲟⲛ ⲉⲣⲁⲧⲛ ϩⲓⲟⲩⲛⲁⲙ ⲙⲡⲣⲣⲟ
Translation: If we ascribe blessings to those who are nigh unto a king in this world, when we see him advancing upon a chariot of gold, and wearing the crown and apparel of purple, then how greatly blessed shall we be when we are placed on the right hand of the King of All, the Judge of every man.

Verse: ⲁⲣⲁ ⲉⲛⲉⲛⲧⲁⲩⲉⲣⲏⲧ
Translation: Now supposing that a kingdom had been promised unto thee, and that the road to the country wherein the kingdom was situated was exceedingly difficult, and toilsome, and was a place of desolation and steepness : wouldst thou not endure all these things in order to reach that kingdom?

Verse: ⲙⲡⲣϫⲟⲟⲥ ϫⲉⲁⲩϣⲣⲡϭⲟⲡⲧ ϩⲛⲛⲁⲛⲟⲃⲉ · ⲙⲛϣϭⲟⲙ ⲙⲙⲟⲓ ⲉⲕⲧⲟⲓ ⲉⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ ·
Translation: Thou shalt not say, I am already snared in my sins, and I am not able to turn myself to God/

Verse: ⲕⲁⲛ ⲉϣϫⲉ ⲁⲡⲇⲓⲁⲃⲟⲗⲟⲥ ϣⲣⲡⲧⲁⲩⲟⲛ ⲉⲡⲉⲥⲏⲧ ⲙⲁⲣⲛⲧⲱⲟⲩⲛ ϩⲛⲟⲩϭⲉⲡⲏ ·
Translation: for even if the Devil hath first of all cast us down headlong, let us rise up quickly.

Verse: ⲡⲉⲛϫⲟⲉⲓⲥ ⲅⲁⲣ ⲟⲩⲙⲁⲓⲣⲱⲙⲉ ⲡⲉ
Translation: For our God is a lover of mankind.

Verse: ϥⲛⲁⲡⲱⲧ ⲉⲃⲟⲗ
Translation: Whomsoever shall flee unto Him He will receive, even as He did in the case of the young man who had squandered the portion of the riches which had fallen to his share.

Verse: ⲙⲡⲣⲧⲣⲉⲙⲡⲟⲣⲛⲟⲥ ⲙⲛⲛⲧⲉⲗⲱⲛⲏⲥ ⲣϣⲟⲣⲡ ⲉⲣⲟⲛ ϩⲛⲧⲙⲛⲧⲣⲣⲟ
Translation: Let no whoremonger and tax-gatherer be before us to enter into the Kingdom.

Verse: ⲟⲩⲛϩⲁϩ ⲙⲡⲁϩⲣⲉ ⲁⲩⲱ ⲟⲩ ⲛⲃⲟⲏⲑⲏⲙⲁ ⲕⲏ ⲛⲁⲛ ⲉϩⲣⲁⲓ ϩⲛⲧⲉⲕⲣⲁⲫⲏ ⲉⲧⲟⲩⲁⲁⲃ ⲉⲩϣⲟⲃⲉ ⲉⲛⲉⲩⲉⲣⲏⲩ ·
Translation: There are many medicines and many remedies established for us in Holy Scripture which are different each from the other.

Verse: ⲁⲭⲁⲃ ⲁϥⲙⲕⲁϩ ⲛϩⲏⲧ ⲉϫⲙⲡⲛⲟⲃⲉ ⲉⲛⲧⲁϥⲁⲁϥ ⲁϥⲣⲃⲟⲗ ⲉⲧⲟⲣⲅⲏ ⲙⲡⲛⲟⲩⲧⲉ · ϩⲓⲧⲙⲡⲉⲓⲡⲁϩⲣⲉ ·
Translation: Ahab sorrowed in his heart because of the sin which he had committed, and he escaped from the wrath of God by means of this medicine. And Nebuchadnezzar (βαλτασαρ) (escaped) through mercy.
